Jesse and James had stolen all of his Pokemon in his sleep except the one he hated most: Charizard.

Even though Ash Ketchum already had the Boulder, Cascade, Thunder, Rainbow, Soul, Marsh, Volcano, Earth, Candy, Chinese, Umbrella, Cantaloupe, Benign, Upside-down, and Banana Badges, Charizard simply would not listen.

It was one of those days when Ash Ketchum woke up on the wrong side of the bed after a hangover involving seventeen barrels of whiskey when he found himself fighting the ever-arrogant Gary Oak.  As usual, Gary had a stick up his ass and a straw up his nose and a chip on his shoulder and was itching for a fight.

Ash was going to have no bullshit today.

"Go!  Charizard!"

He might as well have used a rock to defeat Gary.  At least he could pick it up and bash it into his skull, at which point Gary might have "fainted".

"Charizard!" Ash screamed at the top of lung.  "You are going to beat Gary's ass, or I will be ripping you a new one!!"

Charizard got up, put on his monocle, sipped some English Breakfast tea and said simply, "No, Ash.  It is I who will be ripping you the new one."

And then he ripped Ash a new one.

<lj-cut>This is yet another one of my articles not based on research, but rather on what I believe to be simple logic.

Our dorm has ping pong balls to rent.  Of course, the balls are made of cheap plastic, and are prone (and expected) to break at any moment.  So when the ping pong ball I was playing with cracked, I took it upstairs to get a new one for rent.  I suspected maybe a fifty sent fee or something.

Five dollars.

That's ten times more than it costs to buy a ping pong ball from the local slot machine.

I was irritated, but the person at the desk told me that I could replace it.  I grudgingly understood that it wasn't her fault and asked to check out yet another one.

I walked downstairs with the ball and noticed there was a crack in it as well.  Apparently, someone had returned it without telling the DA that it was... well... damaged.  I didn't play with the ball and returned it.  Without saying a word.

Then it hit me.

I was returning a damaged ping pong ball.  Why?  Because someone else returned a damaged ping pong ball.  Why?  Because that person didn't want to be charged!  We all had the same motive for returning the damaged ping pong ball; it was so we wouldn't be charged five dollars!!

How stupid, I thought to myself.  How stupid that we would all do this.  Soon enough, no one would rent ping pong balls for fear that they would either break or already be broken.  So what would everyone do?  Purchase their own balls!  Individually, this makes economic sense, because no one would have to pay for a broken one.  However, as a community, we each suffer a 50 cent penalty when we want to play ping pong, as opposed to having the convenience of being able to check out the balls.  If we coordinated our efforts as a community, we would have free balls for rent, but instead we're losing 50 cents to play ping pong.

My point is that charging five dollars is not encouraging honesty.  Being penalized for proper use of equipment is unfair to people, especially to those who borrowed malfunctioning equipment, returned said equipment, and had to bear the blame of breaking said equipment.  It is true that there should be some kind of penalty, but five dollars?  Who's gonna be honest then?

Needless to say, I replaced the ball myself.</lj-cut>

Here's another less formal of my posts, but I figure that I haven't written much in a long time, and I need to do so. Ever get the sense of being stared at? I think all of you can pretty much relate. I don't even have to describe it to you. But what really makes it happen? Because I'm weird, I decided that I'd try this out myself. On my way to classes, I'd focus on people directly in front of me for at least a minute. As they walked in line, I didn't notice them do anything strange, such as slowing down, looking around, or scratching their head. Nothing. The same thing applied for when I was standing in line for lunch. I stared at the back of people's heads. Nothing. I have a friend who says she can literally feel people staring at her. I stared at the back of her head for about a minute. Nothing. Why does it fail when people everywhere (including myself) can seriously feel someone staring at them? I thought about the answer and realized what was wrong with every one of my experiments. I was looking at the back of the head. What would happen if I were in someone's peripherals and staring at them? I haven't tried this out yet, but I believe I would get more interesting results. In his book Blink, Malcolm Gladwell discusses the power of the subconscious, and how it can very good guesses with fewer information than our conscious needs to make the same decisions. Gladwell discusses how students who watched a mere two seconds of a tape of a professor's lecture made similar decisions about the quality of the professor's lectures as those who spent time with the professor for an entire semester. (I took the liberty of trying this out for myself and found my predictions surprisingly accurate. I think the most notable signs happen to be gestures, pauses, and facial expressions, as well as how often the professor must refer to notes.) What's my point? Well, the subconscious would theoretically be far more powerful and observant than the conscious, right? Thus if someone were in your peripherals and staring at you, your subconscious would give off signals of discomfort that indicate that someone is staring at you. Why would your subconscious do that? Probably because when humans were less evolved and lived in the wild, they needed to know when creatures were stalking them so they could identify the creature and get away. There is nothing magical about feeling that someone is staring at you. But there is something magical about how peripherals can identify out of a pair of hundreds of eyes those two that could be potentially dangerous. --- REFERENCE: Gladwell, M. (2007). Blink: The power of thinking without thinking. New York, NY: Back Bay Books.

There was a Dateline special about iPod thefts. Dateline discusses how it might theoretically be possible to track down iPods, because iPods are supposed to be registered online. I think you can see where this is going; this information could be used to track down possible thieves. The special mainly discusses how it used a special program to make the installation CD appear to be a normal CD, but the program in the CD gives the private information not only to Apple, but also to Dateline. The people eventually track down the thieves and confront them, usually regaining the iPods. Then the story brings about an interesting question: What if Apple used the private information to track down possible thieves? Aside from the obvious liability issue, in which no private information received from registration is to be released without the registrar's consent, I think this is an interesting topic to ponder. What incentive does Apple have to track down these individuals? According to Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner (2006), "Morality, it could be argued, represents the way that people would like the world to work -- whereas economics represents how it actually does work" (p. 11). The two continue to state that "[i]ncentives are the cornerstone of modern life" (p. 11). This truth seems (to me) to apply more to large corporations rather than individuals (though I will spare the government from this discussion, as it is sometimes, believe it or not, an institution that defends society). So what incentive does Apple have? Surely a large corporation won't begin hunting down iPod thieves because it's the "right thing to do". Customer service in your favorite supermarket or electronic stores does not exist for the sake of altruism. It exists because these stores want repeat customers, and in a country where competitive prices make most similar products equally low in price, one of the few ways to bring back customers is via customer service. It's the same reason why some "Mom 'n' Pop" stores can still survive today. However, Apple is already well-known (apparently) for great customer support. And if the company already has great customer support, it doesn't need to build more status for "great customer support". Additionally, Apple isn't exactly obligated to locate lost merchandise (unless it's their own fault that the merchandise was lost, as in shipping orders). By refusing to locate lost merchandise, Apple probably won't lose too much status. So if Apple won't relocate lost merchandise, what will the customers end up doing? They'll buy another one. Why not? Why buy something from someone else if you were already satisfied with the product you had before? By refusing to relocate lost merchandise, Apple can actually increase sales. Dateline continues its program by asking thieves whether or not they would have stolen the iPods had they known that stolen iPods could be traced. Of course, every thief said "no". What would happen if iPod's method for detecting thieves was flawless and could catch, say, 90% of thieves? Those thieves would simply purchase the product themselves! What would happen? Sales would go up! Ah, but what if the iPod catching was about as effective as, say, the IRS catching tax evaders (sorry, I know I said that I was going to leave the government out...)? Well, you'd get people stealing iPods, while the occasional thief gets caught. Essentially, the situation would look similar to what would happen if Apple did nothing at all, right? You'd get many people just repurchasing the product back anyway, while thieves would have little incentive to stop stealing. Same situation, but we add a few more winners into the mix, right? Not quite. It takes time to track down said thieves. That, and it would probably take time to actually be able to confront the thief. Time is definitely valuable. Therefore (if I may sound like a faux logician for a moment), companies would be losing money. Companies lose out. Few customers are satisfied with even better service than usual. Other customers are disappointed that they aren't getting their stolen iPods back. Still more customers will wait to see if their iPod will be found instead of buying a new one. As a result, fewer iPods are bought, Apple loses face, and Apple loses money. I suppose the only thing that could come out of this is more jobs to track down said thieves, but that would lose even more money, so Apple probably wouldn't do it anyway. My point is that Apple can't do half of the job. It's all or nothing. They can't do a pathetic job like the IRS that simply lands them in a lose-lose situation. Of course, it's a lot easier to do nothing, so guess what Apple probably will do? It's an interesting solution you propose, Dateline, but unfortunately, large corporations revolve around incentives rather than morals. --- REFERENCE Levitt, S. D. and S. J. Dubner. (2006). Freakonomics: A rogue economist explores the hidden side of everything. New York, NY: HarperCollins Publishers.

I was discussing my major with my dermatologist a while back. I told her that I originally planned to do optical engineering, but recently decided against it, in favor of (what I believe to be) the more exciting fields of either economics or marketing. She told me that she understood m attitude. She said she understood that I wanted to "change the world". "Change the world?" I thought, "I'd be a surgeon if I wanted to do that. I'm just looking for something interesting that puts food on the table." Effective marketing does, in a sense, change the world. McDonald's is an example of stellar marketing. According to Eric Schlosser (2005), "A survey of American schoolchildren found that 96 percent could identify Ronald McDonald. The only fictional character with a higher degree of recognition was Santa Claus. The impact of McDonald's on the way we live today is hard to overstate. The Golden Arches are now more widely recognized than the Christian cross" (pp. 4-5). Besides the disturbing point that McDonald's is more recognized than a prominent religious symbol in the United States, it shows how good marketing molds people's ideas. In the July 7-13 2007 issue of The Economist, one article (p. 74) discusses how to more easily understand exchange rates by converting currency not to other currency, rather, to Big Macs. The article itself is interesting in teaching about exchange rates and such, but what I find more striking is the vast amount of countries that sell Big Macs (32 countries are listed in the article), which is a clear indicator of McDonald's shaping of the world. Notably, the Big Mac has "changed the world", but not necessarily for the better. So how does one use marketing to change the world for the better? Perhaps its easiest if I discuss one of the simplest forms of advertisement -- signs. --- BAD SIGNS I was riding from San Francisco to Pleasanton (where my grandmother lives) when I noticed some billboards on the highway. None of them were particlarly interesting and some were downright annoying. I saw a billboard for (what I assumed was) real estate advertisement. It was essentially a billboard split into four signs, each advertising its own company, and each advertising just what was so amazing about their "unique" company. I tried to memorize the sign so I might write out its features here, but it had so much information (yet so little useful information) that I gave up. I saw another advertisement on my way to the airport (which is where I am writing the original article right now). The picture had a girl standing while holding a phone. There was an arrow at her feet. In the background were various rees lit up by the night sky. It was a beautiful looking poster, only I had no idea what it was trying to advertise. I needed to squint to see a small Sprint logo in the upper-right corner. Terrible marketing, if one doesn't even understand what the product itself is supposed to be. --- A GOOD SIGN I was on the same drive from San Francisco that I mentioned before when I noticed what I believed to be a nearly perfect sign. The sign was ironic in that it was far less budgeted than the other signs; it was about four times smaller, and was attached to a light pole via tape. It was cardboard decorated with red paint, and had exactly two words. Fresh cherries. There was an arrow under the two words, and a painting of a cherry. It was an amazing sign because it told what was sold (cherries), what was so good about them (fresh), and where they were (with the arrow). I saw the sign at about the same time and speed as I saw the real estate sign and Spring sign, yet I instantly had a craving for fresh cherries. --- BETTER USES OF MARKETING There are good signs that easily get three main points across, and there are terrible signs that, well, don't. What do I think makes a good sign? I'm no professional, but I think I'm entitled to an opinion here. After all, I am the target of marketing, and marketers should have to follow my opinions. Here are three questions that every good sign must answer: 1. What is being sold? 2. What's so good about this product? 3. How do I get this product? So you ponder these three questions and think that perhaps I'm making sense (or not), but you look back to the subtitle of this section and ask your self if I'm ever going to get to the point. Becase I do, in fact, have a point. I was passing down a highway (what can I say? highways are good places to find billboards!!) from Arizona to California, and noticed a sign. It had a yellow background and bold black text. It was easy to spot and very easy to understand its message. I glanced at it for maybe three seconds. I suppose I will remember this billboard for a long time, because not only was it a great billboard, but... Well, it was set up in the style of a checklist. There were two boxes: __ do nothing __ fightglobalwarming.com Needless to say, I'm currently signed up for their newsletter. And THAT, my friends, is my point. --- REFERENCES Schlosser, E. (2005). Fast food nation: The dark side of the all-American meal. New York, NY: Harper Perennial (2007, July 7). The Big Mac index: Sizzling. The Economist, 384, 74-74.

"Even a broken clock is right twice a day." It's an interesting statement. In fact, it's rather interesting to compare a broken clock to a clock that works. For a clock that works is hardly ever right. A clock that works is simply an estimation of the time. For if the clock is even a millisecond wrong, it is wrong. It will never be spot-on like the broken clock is twice a day. Clocks are kind of like science. Note Nassim Taleb's (2005) take on astrology: "A theory that does not present a set of conditions under which it would be considered wrong would be termed charlatanism -- it would be impossible to reject otherwise. Why? Because the astrologist can always find a reason to fit the past event, by saying that Mars was probably in line but not too much so..." (p. 126) In that sense, astrology will always be correct, similar to how a broken clock will always be right twice a day. Now consider Karl Popper's take on science (as cited by Taleb, 2004): "Popper's idea is that science is not to be taken as seriously as it sounds... There are only two types of theories: "1. Theories that are known to be wrong, as they were tested and adequately rejected (he calls them falsified). "2. Theories that have not yet been known to be wrong, not falsified yet, but are exposed to be proved wrong." Taleb explains that a theory can never be right because you can never know all of the information about the world in order to verify your claim. Taleb uses the example of the black swan, in which all swans were believed to be white. Therefore the theory "All swans are white." came about. Note that the presence of a single black swan would destroy said theory (and did destroy said theory). Ironically, science is science because it can be falsified. We know that science is imperfect and prone to various fallacies. Notice that astrology, on the other hand, is always right. It can never be disproved. I propose, therefore, that astrology is like a broken clock, bound to be right no matter what. I also propose, therefore, that science is like a working clock. It is constantly adjusted to get closer to the truth, but is never quite there. I leave my reader with the following question: Why is it that we prefer to have our clocks working while seconds or minutes off, rather than a broken clock that must tell the right time twice a day? --- REFERENCES Talem, N. N. (2005). Fooled by randomness: The hidden role of chance in life and in the markets. New York, NY: Random House.

So I was preparing dinner today at 12:30 pm (it was a slow-cook dinner, and my dad asked me to prepare a few things at about noonish), when my brother started complaining about... well.. something. I walked over to his computer, and found him staring at this review for Super Metroid, a game for the SNES that is very highly rated by many gamers, and a game that my brother just happens to love playing right now. This review was unusual in that it gave the game a 4/10, as opposed to most every other review. (As a side note, only 3 of the 54 reviews gave it less than a 9/10. 44 of the 54 reviews gave it a perfect score.) I skimmed through the review and, though I had little interest in the game personally, much less its reviews, I could understand why the author would rate it the way he did. The review breaks down thusly: Graphics: 10/10 Sound: 10/10 Controls: 10/10 Gameplay: 4/10 Replay Value: 2/10 Overall: 4/10 I read through the review briefly, and absolutely agreed with him in certain areas. (For example, the soundtrack for that game is amazing, especially for a SNES game.) I didn't agree with him in certain parts (such as gameplay), but I understood why he would make such allegations against the game. After all, it is pretty repetitive. Of course, the review does come off as very slightly narcissistic, especially when the author says such things as, "With all the tens this game is getting, it's hard to think I'm giving this game an overall rating of a four!" However, I could fully understand his argument against the game, and found no problems with the review. I asked my brother what his problem with the review was. After he told me his reason, I chuckled a little inside. He complained that the values didn't average to an overall value of 4/10. It is a true observation. The mean score of all values prior to the overall score is 7.2/10. A respectable score for any video game, to be sure. There are two possible reasons why my brother would make such an argument. One reason is because he didn't understand English teachers. The other reason is because he was emotional. In both cases, his failure to understand the reviewer's overall score of 4/10 was not his fault at all. --- ABOUT ENGLISH TEACHERS My English teacher from my senior year in high school, we'll call her Ms. H., had very strong ideals about teaching. I won't get into particulars, but one policy she felt strongly about was how papers were graded. Teachers (or, at least the teachers I have had) usually acquire a rubric (or set of rubrics) to grade essays. The rubrics will address such things as voice, conventions, grammar, syntax, etc. The natural idea behind rubrics is to assign a score for each section, and ultimately add those scores together to give a final score. It's a fast and simple way of getting the work done, and it is understandable why teachers would want to have a fast and simple way of getting papers finished. Some teachers have hundreds of papers to grade, for crying out loud! Ms. H. views the rubrics as a set of guidelines, however. For example, a graded paper might have the following scores: A: 9/10 B: 5/10 C: 8/10 D: 7/10 E: 9/10 Score: 85% The score, if simply adding up the numbers, should be a 38/50, or a 76%. So why would Ms. H. grade so much higher than what the rubric says the score should be? Is it because she is playing favorites? Ms. H. explains her grading system, and explains how the rubrics are more like guidelines. She'll tell the class, for example, that in certain papers, voice might be far more important than conventions and spelling errors, or that the structure of the essay is the most important part. Reviewing the review of Super Metroid, gameplay and replay value are probably the most important aspects of video games. It's the reason why the PS3 is still available at every Target, while you'd still be hard-pressed to find the Nintendo Wii at just any store. Of course, my brother may not have had such an idea introduced to him yet, as some of his teachers just check off the answer sheets for right or wrong answers, or just mark up the rubric to eventually give a C for a paper that actually deserved a B. He cannot be expected to apply something he hasn't yet learned about. --- ABOUT EMOTIONS There is still another reason why he might have failed to understand how a 4/10 could be pulled from a set of scores whose average is 7.2/10. Paul Ekman (2003) writes about facial expressions and emotions, and has been studying both for many years. In his book Emotions Revealed, one expects to read a book about how you can tell whether someone is happy or sad or angry simply by looking for eyelids drooping about a millimeter lower than usual, or eyebrows moving together just slightly more than usual. Of course, the book does discuss all of this, but not before discussing how we become emotional, and what happens when we become emotional. Paul Ekman describes how emotions change our facial expressions, physical self, and how we view the world. He also describes an interesting feature about emotions. Ekman writes about a "refractory state". Ekman describes this state as a certain time while we are experiencing our emotions in which "our thinking cannot incorporate information that does not fit, maintain, or justify the emotion we are feeling" (p. 39). It's usually true. Whenever we are angry, be it at a spouse or a sibling or a friend, we don't try to reason other possible explanations. When a child is standing in the same room as a broken vase, we don't question whether or not the child has broken the vase. We know. We immediately send the child to his room, and don't search for alternate explanations, such as the vase having been broken before and the child walking to the bathroom at the same time, or the child running to the vase after hearing it break out of curiosity. We are in the refractory period. We are angry, and we need only look at the evidence that justifies our anger. Now, we can apply the idea of the refractory period to my brother's situation. He really liked the game Super Metroid, and didn't want to see evidence to the contrary. When he saw a review that gave it a low score, he must have felt slightly annoyed or frustrated. When he began reading the review, he saw that the average should have been around 7/10, and was annoyed that the person (apparently) didn't understand basic algebra. This made him more annoyed. He probably looked at the reasoning behind the overall score and became more annoyed. This annoyance caused him to go into a refractory state, and during the refractory state, my brother reasoned that bad math is what gave the bad score. He reasoned that the reviewer was a dunce and didn't understand basic algebra. He didn't try to understand the reviewer. He didn't try to understand that maybe replay value and gameplay were far more important than graphics or sound. In fact, he probably didn't even see those words. All he saw was: 10/10 + 10/10 + 10/10 + 4/10 + 2/10 = 20/50. All he saw was the evidence that supported his emotions. --- THE CONCLUSION Ekman constantly writes throughout his book that emotions are important. They make life interesting. They (sometimes) guide our search in the right directions. They motivate us. However, sometimes we need to tell our emotions to slow down so we can have a better understanding about the situation. It's an idea that needs to be applied more often. Consider religious views. Some people have religious views that are different than others. Is it worth killing for? Some people say yes. Perhaps these people are killing over religion because seeing others with different views makes them angry. They are stuck in a refractory period in which the only information they can receive about the other person is: "They are stupid. How could you not believe in something that I believe in? Because you would be stupid. Stupid stupid stupid." These people don't try to understand why a person might have different views than them. In fact, these people don't even try to understand why they are so angry. If they would simply reflect upon themselves for a minute, if they would ask themselves, "Why am I angry about this?" Perhaps they would be able to stop their anger and learn to accept others' religious views. So maybe when someone is saying, "I don't understand", what they really mean is "I won't understand." --- REFERENCES Ekman, P. (2003). Emotions revealed: Recognizing faces and feelings to improve communication and emotional life. New York, NY: Owl Books. WrestlingRPGFan, (2001, Nov. 3). Game... so... overrated... [Review of the video game Super Metroid]. Retrieved on 21 June 2007 from http://www.gamefaqs.com/console/snes/review/R25473.html.

So I was lying on my couch reading a book (Emotions Revealed by Paul Ekman, and yes, it is slightly relevant to this discussion). My brother was sitting on another couch playing his Nintendo DS. I put my book down for a few seconds to take a quick breather, when I noticed that Jerry Springer was on television. It was some episode called "Audience Attack", and I was waiting for a riot to happen. The episode has a man with extremely long hair (that is, longer than how long my hair was, or how long Chelsea L.'s hair is). He looked dirty and was probably in his forties. He didn't exactly show much facial expression, though he did show quite a bit of poorly-shaven facial hair. Anyway, he was talking about how he wanted to live on the streets for some reason, and his wife disapproved of his idea. The scene then cut to a (rather staged) dramatization of what he and his wife were going through. He would try to explain to her that he just wanted to live on the streets, and she would constantly show annoyance and physically assault him. She eventually ended up leaving, and he eventually ended up (pretending to be) sleeping. Aside from the obvious question, "How would someone get a video clip of something like that without the lady stabbing the cameraman in the heart?" I also asked myself, "Why would anyone watch this kind of show?" The lady was trying to physically assault her husband on stage, and people were cheering, and security guards that must have weighed at least 200 pounds were having trouble restraining this 5'6" lady from assaulting her husband. It was mind-numbingly stupid. There was a scenario after that regarding a woman who had only one leg and no arms. The lady complained about her husband never helping her around the house. The scene then cut to her trying to eat spaghetti, eat chips, and drink a soda. She was even talking with the cameraman while making a fool out of herself. I'm not one to lightly call disabled people fools, nor would I call anyone a fool ordinarily. However, this lady was obviously just trying to dramatize how difficult it was for her to eat. Someone with no arms won't try to eat a meatball. They'll just go for the pasta instead. Someone with no arms won't try to open a bag of chips. They'll eat something more accessible. Someone with no arms won't try to drink a soda out of a can. They'll use a straw. Each situation showed the lady making a fool out of herself as she (apparently) failed at life (and, incidentally, said "shucks" after every failure). The volume was turned down low so you would have to really concentrate on what was going on to hear, and what I heard were not gasps of horror. Rather, I heard a chorus of laughter. Laughter after each failure of what this woman tried to do. No pity. I disgustedly turned the TV off. Within the three minute time span that I watched "Jerry", I think my IQ might have temporarily dropped 15 points. I returned to my book, and read the following passage: "Sometimes a person... may be regarded as not being really human... Their suffering may seem deserved, or at least not discomforting to the witness. There are also people who enjoy the suffering of others. They torment, physically or psychologically, because it feels good to exert their power and to witness the pain and suffering it produces." Paul Ekman continues, implying that people who cannot empathize may be similar to sociopaths. Indeed, upon looking at the next chapter which discusses anger, violence is termed as a mental disorder, and discusses people who absolutely love hurting others, be it mentally or physically. So I thought about Jerry Springer, and thought to myself, "Perhaps it is that Jerry Springer and his audiences are all... to some degree... psychopaths." It's hard to see how this is not the case. Staging fights for midday television that nobody watches. People cheering for violence. Thinking in terms of Levitt and Dubner as they describe in their book Freakonomics, there is no economical or social incentive to watch the show. Additionally, there is a negative moral incentive to watch the show. So why would anyone watch it? The only reason someone would watch such a show is for pleasure, and the only pleasure that can come from that show would be that pleasure in watching others suffer. Someone who gains pleasure from watching others suffer is, essentially, a psychopath. It's hard not to see a link between Jerry Springer and being a psychopath. I believe the more interesting question in this case is, "Do psychopaths watch Jerry Springer because they're psychopaths, or does Jerry Springer make people psychopaths?" Of course, as of now, I have no evidence to begin answering that question. --- References: Ekman, P. (2007). Emotions revealed: Recognizing faces and feelings to improve communication and emotional life. New York, NY: Owl Books. Levitt, S. D. & Dubner, S. J. (2006). Freakonomics: a rogue economist explores the hidden side of everything. New York, NY: HarperCollins.

Constantly, we are taught of the importance of analyzing and gathering more information before making an important decision. Always weigh the pros and cons before making a decision, especially if it's an important one that will consume plenty of time and/or money. It's a generally good rule. After all, who would want to purchase a car before comparing the pros and cons among various cars? It's a big decision, and being careless would have extremely detrimental consequences. A crappy car won't do, and a good, but less than perfect car is difficult to sell, even new. After all, a perfectly fine, new car must lose about a quarter of its value as soon as it leaves the lot with its owner. After all, the only reason a person would want to resell the car is because the owner found it to be a "lemon" (Levitt & Dubner, 2006). No, only a perfect car would do, and the only way to find the perfect car must be through days of deliberation, gathering all possible data available. It's a job best left to analysis, not intuition. Consider heart attacks. Doctors in the emergency room must make decisions about whether or not a patient is at high or low risk of having one. How would one go about making the decision? Obviously, by gathering data. But how much data should one find out? Do we need to know age? Past medical history? Income? Where the person lives? How much the person weighs? How tall the person is? Body temperature? Electrocardiograms? Heart rate? Blood pressure? Gender? The time it would take to gather absolutely as much information as possible to make a well-educated guess would be simply too time-consuming. Let's say you want to find out ten pieces of information. How would you evaluate this information? Does age matter more than weight? How about dietary information? I think by the time a doctor would calculate all of this data, the patient would be in another room, and the doctor would be out of a job. Gerd Gigerenzer, Peter M. Todd, and the ABC Research Group released a book in 1999 entitled Simple Heuristics That Make Us Smart. The book basically discusses heuristics, and making quick and smart decisions. The premise of the book obviously gives away the solution to the heart attack problem, though one might be surprised to find that it takes only three cues to rather accurately predict whether or not a person should be admitted as "high risk" or "low risk". Gigerenzer, Todd, and the ABC Research Group cite Breiman and fellow colleagues as having developed a kind of flow chart to determine risk. The chart is as follows: 1. Is the minimum systolic blood pressure over the initial 24 hour period >91? Yes = Go to next step. No = High risk. 2. Is age >62.5? Yes = Go to next step. No = Low risk. 3. Is sinus tachycardia present? Yes = High risk. No = Low risk. It's simple. At most, one would have to answer three questions to find out high or low risk. Additionally, there is no quantifying how important each item is. It's a yes-or-no answer, and you move on. Additionally, it is more accurate than other ideas of taking and evaluating dozens of medical cues, as if the amount of time saved isn't appealing enough (Gigerenzer et. al., 1999). Overanalysis has its drawbacks, and therefore, Malcolm Gladwell, author of Blink: The Power of Thinking without Thinking cites Freud as stating that more minor decisions should be left to the conscious, while more major decisions should be made by the unconscious (Gladwell, 2007, p. 268). That's fine. Let's consider a situation, then, in which one is to make a decision of what to wear to work today. Consider that one shirt is blue and has seven buttons, while the other shirt is blue and has eight buttons. I hope that one would not spend too much time deliberating over which shirt is better. This concept is what Gary Klein, author of The Power of Intuition calls the "Zone of Indifference" (2003, p. 77). Even if it's a minor decision, that decision could be easily settled and easily have time saved simply by allowing intuition to do its work. Consider another anecdote of minor decision making. EVR is an intelligent man whose IQ consistently is tested into the 97th-99th percentile. EVR had cerebral brain tumor at the age of 35, and eventually had it removed, though not before it slightly damaged both frontal lobes of his brain. The surgery was a success, and EVR would return to his daily life routine, though he would not quite be the same. For example, "deciding where to dine might take hours, as he discussed each restaurant's seating plan, particulars of menu, atmosphere and management. He would drive to each restaurant to see how busy it was, but even then he could not finally decide which to choose" (Klein, 2003, p. 79). Oh, and concerning the car, Malcolm Gladwell discusses psychologist Ap Dijksterhuis's experiment about how accurately people would choose cars. Essentially, the cars had already been evaluated by experts, and a "better" one was already pre-chosen by said experts. There were two groups of people in the experiment, one group were shown characteristics of the car and later asked to evaluate which was better. The other group was shown the same characteristics, but distracted with anagrams. At the end of the experiment, both groups were to evaluate which car was better. Those who deliberated about the car without interruption had about 20% accuracy in evaluating the better vehicle, while those who were distracted and paid less attention had about 60% accuracy. Perhaps the question about intuition is not about intuition at all. Perhaps the question should be asking why we need to overanalyze issues. --- Sources: Gigerenzer, G. & Todd, P. M. (1999). Simple heuristics that make us smart. New York, NY: Oxford University Press. Gladwell, M. (2007). Blink: The power of thinking without thinking. New York, NY: Back Bay Books. Klein, G. (2003). The power of intuition: How to use your gut feelings to make better decisions at work. New York, NY: Currency Doubleday. Levitt, S. D. & Dubner, S. J. (2006). Freakonomics: a rogue economist explores the hidden side of everything. New York, NY: HarperCollins.

The title of this article isn't exactly catchy by any means, but I suppose it is fitting as a literal description of what this is about to be. I used to be in a high school choir that was split up into separate sub-units, if you will. There were the beginning, show, advanced, and jazz choirs. I happened to be a member of the show and jazz choirs, while maintaining a few ties to the beginning and show choirs, which mostly came about through being friends/acquaintances of others who happened to be in, say, show and jazz choirs, or beginning and advanced choirs. (Yes, beginning and advanced choirs. Some students decide to join both choirs because the director thinks it beneficial to have some better students encourage the beginners to sing better, though this seems ineffective even in "advanced" choir.) I joined the choir sophomore year, and at that time, everyone was fine with the choir director and her style. She was nice and always encouraged everyone to make new friends. She would hold "choir socials", and for the choir trips, she would assign "buddies" to keep the choir together as a "family". It worked. Everyone was happy and nice and everyone liked the director. People would, in fact, volunteer to help out with rummage sales and other fundraising activities. It was probably the best year that choir had. Junior year rolled around, and suddenly, she seemed to be less involved in the choir. The socials were less frequent, and those who didn't happen to go on the choir tour trip didn't have "buddies". Some of the seniors started complaining about her. However, the rest of us (underclassmen) were still fine with her. The choir was still a very good choir, and we still tried very hard, and we had a lot of fun. Senior year came, and suddenly, everyone hated our director. Within the first two months, she was easily everyone's most hated teacher. During the time, I couldn't quite figure out why she was such a dreadful person to be around; she was the same person. She had the same habits. She looked the same. Yet in the time span of five months or so, everyone grew to absolutely detest her. In hindsight, and after reading Malcolm Gladwell's The Tipping Point, the solution is very simple. --- THE LAW OF THE FEW I remember a student, Mikaela S. She happened to have ties with every choir. Rather close ties at that. She was in the beginning, advanced, jazz, and show choirs (if I recall correctly). She absolutely loved our director and thought that everything she did was great. And she knew everyone. She was a Connector, and when she told people about things, people listened because people knew her. Everyone knew her. She quit Junior year, and took all her approvals of our director with her. Senior year came, and many seniors at that time happened to become Connectors. All seniors had ties either directly or indirectly with each choir. All seniors could, collectively, say something, and the idea would cross everyone's minds in the choir. Whether it went in one ear and out the other, or sticked was a different question entirely, but everyone was hearing the message. Naturally, when we would say that the teacher was terrible, they would listen and agree that she was terrible. I remember having a conversation with Derek O., one of the few students that I happened to have ties with in the beginning choir. We were talking about choir, and he mentioned to me how he hated the choir director. I found this shocking, because I didn't remember any other "Connectors" from choir having talked to him about the choir director. I agreed with him and asked him why he thought that way, and he told me that he had heard rumors about how she was constantly stealing money from the other accounts that were originally supposed to pay for improvements for choir in order to fund her family's going on the tour as well. I hadn't heard that before, but I agreed and thought that that must have been the case. After all, it did make sense. How else would she fund the tours? Out of her own pocket? Not likely. --- THE STICKINESS FACTOR However, she had always done such a thing, so why was it that she wasn't hated sophomore and junior year, but so despised senior year? There was one very big event senior year that seemed to spark the whole epidemic of hate. Ryan F. was (arguably) the best bass in choir, and perhaps the best male in choir. He and the choir director didn't exactly see eye-to-eye on many things, including how after school dress rehearsals should be mandatory. He had his father e-mail the choir teacher about possibly making up the assignment another way, as he was never able to get a proper response when asking her directly. The choir director responded by saying that Ryan F. was a "liar" and had apparently not been very dedicated to choir at all. After the first semester, Ryan F. dropped choir, and at that time, people had a definite reason to hate her. You can't call a student names, and you can't kick your best choir member out of choir. The message was a sticky one. It applied directly to every student in choir. The teacher kicked out one of the Connectors in choir, so naturally everyone knew about it, even without the other Connectors telling them. The teacher kicked out the best bass in choir. If the best bass was out, how good could the rest of the choir possibly be then? --- THE LAW OF CONTEXT However, this doesn't explain very much about why the students originally hated her. It's simple, though many students probably won't notice it. This year, we had a grand total of zero fund raisers. This year, we had a grand total of zero choir socials. This year, we had no "buddies" for the choir tour. This year, there were no renovations to the choir room or to the choir itself. It was the little things that ultimately counted. Without the Ryan F. incident, everyone would still hate the director, except they wouldn't know why. The little things was what made the choir a family unit. It was what made the choir happy. People always looked forward to choir socials. People always looked forward to the "buddy" system. People always enjoyed renovations. As a result of these little things, people would enjoy participating in fund raisers. Without those little things in place that made choir a happy family unit, the choir fell apart. --- CONCLUSION The book is excellent in that it puts epidemics in a new light and gives ways to (accurately) define "epidemics". Epidemics don't always have to be fashion trends. They don't always have to be viruses. Epidemics could be ideas, and the spread of certain ideas can make an excellent choir, or destroy one.

<lj-cut>Vanished.  As if someone could hide a 15 x 20 foot painting, much less run off with the thing, and yet the impossible seemed true!

Everyone surveyed the room quickly and noted the only items of interest were the open windows, the piano, and the previously received package, still wrapped as it was when it just arrived.

Arthur ran to the window and looked out for any signs of prints or whatnot, but it was no use.  Vincent Jefferson would never leave something so rediculously simple at the scene of the crime, or so everyone at the "party" thought to themselves.

And it was true.  The ground was muddy, yet no footprints were to be found.  The window... it might have been a ploy... and yet...

"He has it hidden somewhere.... I know it!" shouted Arthur Chester, as he frantically searched the entire room.  Dr. Hadean cast a suspicious glance toward the butler guarding the door.

"It's quite simple, really," Dr. Hadean muttered to himself.

Arthur Chester, however, decided that he would do better to tear down everything in the room in case Vincent Jefferson had somehow hidden it without anyone noticing.

Suddenly, Arthur smiled as he cast a short glance to the obnoxiously large package he had previously received.

"Ha!"

He tore open the package and... there was Arsene Lupin!

"You didn't get away this time, Vincent Jefferson," Arthur shouted in triumph.  Louisa rushed to Arthur, shoved him out of the way, and planted a small kiss onto the painting.

Suddenly, a short laugh came out of Skip Carter.  The room hushed up and stared at him, for it was a queer thing to do with such a serious matter.

"You're all blind!" he shouted.  "Look!  Look behind the painting!"

Arthur bent behind the painting, and gasped.  Louisa rushed behind it and did the same.  Everyone began to notice something appalling behind the painting of Arsene Lupin.

Behind that painting, was another canvas.  The first canvas was removed to reveal Arsene Lupin!  That canvas was removed to reveal Arsene Lupin once again!  In fact, there were about two dozen Arsene Lupins in the room, all smiling and taunting its owner.

"What is the meaning of this?!" Arthur shouted in his characteristic voice.

"If that's so," said Bethany, "why would there be multiple copies rather than just one?  In fact, there are at least two dozens, are there not?"

Everyone agreed that it was a strange state of affairs.

"Wait!" shouted Martin suddenly, as an idea struck him.  "Perhaps the painting has had some kind of water mark?  Surely, Vincent Jefferson could not have known of the water mark, and could not have prepared a painting with a water mark on it if he had just removed the painting today."

Louisa was excited at the idea, and Arthur sent out the butler guarding the door to fetch a flashlight, as if he were a king and ordering some peon to leave his castle, lest he should bring his wrath upon the poor fellow.  The butler rushed off, almost tripping on his own shoes.

The butler returned with a flashlight momentarily, and Arthur Chester grabbed the flashlight and rushed to shine it behind every painting of Arsene Lupin to find its authenticity.

Each painting was held, and the flashlight was shone upon the back of each one, so as to find some kind of water mark.  Of course, the canvas was so tall, that eventually a ladder was needed to reach the higher parts of the painting.

"Ah!"

Arthur uttered a squeal of delight, and the others awed as well, for in that very painting they were all holding, Arsene Lupin's face had become distorted into a likeness of a beautiful ring.  It was a queer water mark, thought Dr. Hadean, but the thought passed him without much concern.

The real painting of Arsene Lupin was restored to its rightful place.

"Take that!" shouted Arthur Chester, casting glances at Skip Carter, Kerry Manfred, and the butler.  "You see, Arsene Lupin might be able to pull a fast one on many people, but he is still just a man!"  He smiled as he took credit for Dr. Hadean's previous remark.  Dr. Hadean looked uncomfortable.

---

Hours longer had passed, as the rest of the mansion was surveyed.  Guests were beginning to leave, as the party was dying.

"Before you leave, however," said Arthur Chester, standing next to the enormous front door, "I would like to give you all a parting gift."

He snapped his fingers, and a butler and housemaid brought out the copies of Arsene Lupin.  Some were terribly excited by this, and some cast short smiles, but all were pleased to receive their parting gift, even if it was a fake.

"I believe," continued Arthur Chester, "that we should all give our thanks to Vincent Jefferson.  For without him, we wouldn't have had this delicious comedy that we have now!"

Everyone laughed except Dr. Hadean, who quietly accepted his painting, and stole out the door.  Each person carefully surveyed the paintings before choosing the one that they believed looked most authentic.

"Bethany..."

Bethany Shadows was the second-to-last to leave, and Martin Pershing stood without a painting, casting his eyes upon Bethany.  Her figure was faintly visible in the dark outside...

"Thank you for a great time," Martin said awkwardly, as he held out his hand for her to shake.  Bethany grabbed his hand and seemed as if she wanted to kiss him, but Martin refused.  He simply smiled and let her walk out the door with her painting being carried out to the car by two maids.

"Well," said Louisa Chester.  "I bid you good night."  It wasn't subtle by any means of the word.

Martin examined the backs of the remaining paintings quickly, and chose one.  He waved good night and carried the painting out to a delivery truck.  Arthur Chester had evidently ordered one for every guest, so the truck could follow the guest to their abode, and deliver it properly.  Martin handed a small slip of paper to one of the maids as she opened the door to the delivery truck.  He also handed a small slip of paper to the man driving the delivery truck.

"That's strange," said Arthur Chester, after Martin Pershing had left.

"What's strange?" asked Louisa Chester.

"It's strange that that queer fellow would go one way to his house, while the truck driver should take another way..."

The maid rushed back into the mansion and said, "This is addressed to you from that Mr. Martin Pershing."  She continued inside to finish the rest of her menial tasks.

"What is it?" asked Louisa Chester with little interest.

She got no response, however.  Arthur Chester stood in the doorway, with the door still open.  His eyes were wide and his mouth was slightly agape.  The paper dropped to the floor.  Writing was all over the front and back of the sheet.

"Arthur?"

Louisa Chester rushed to the doorway and picked up the scrap of paper.  It read:

---

Dearest Sir Arthur Jeiger Candide Frankstein Chester III, esq. and Louisa Chester:
I truly must thank the two of you for allowing me to take your prized Arsene Lupin painting.  In fact, I must thank Arthur Chester for outright giving it to me.  It really is a pleasure to be able to relieve you of such a valuable, and especially because it should belong in a museum.

You will notice that I have sent you other copies of Arsene Lupin, including the one that, no doubt, hangs in your art room right now.  It truly is a good imitation, isn't it?  Especially with that water mark.  I have taken great pains to have it created in so special a manner, but it is definitely beautiful.

But perhaps you are wondering what is my trick?  And I shall tell you!  It was very simple, actually!  All I did was send you the paintings!  I had wrapped yours in the same paper when you weren't looking, and you just assumed that the one with the water mark (which was a fake, and which I had sent you in the first place) was the real one.  Perhaps, if you did your own work and weren't so caught up in buying expensive things, you would have realized this sooner, rather than right now, for the real painting of Arsene Lupin has a dab of red paint directly behind the left eye at the back of the canvas.

I knew no one would take that one, because it appeared as if the painting was damaged.  That is why I had such an easy time receiving it from you, and for that, I truly must thank you.

You will note, Mr. and Mrs. Chester, that the water mark is the shape of a ring.  That ring signifies what else has been taken from you, and should be remembered as a token of your foolishness.

Faithfully and Sincerely Yours,
Vincent Jefferson

---

Louisa Chester rushed up the stairs and pushed on the lids of every jewelry box.  She approached the rather large case with the rather small ring and noticed that the ring was gone!  It was her most prized possession!  Gone!  Louisa screamed a cry of terror...

---

Martin Pershing drove home confidently, and the next day had exchanged the ring for money at a pawn shop.  He enclosed the money in an envelope along with a short message saying, "For Child Support", and added two addressed to the envelope.  He smiled.  He had gone into his profession for the right reasons.

Martin Pershing bought a ticket to the local museum that same day and admired the painting of Arsene Lupin.

"Arsene Lupin..." he said to himself.  "A man of many faces... As am I..."

Vincent Jefferson stared at himself in the glass case that housed Arsene Lupin.  He noticed the few defining features he had left.  He stared at a middle-aged man... He was still in shape... If he were ten or twenty years younger...

And his grey eyes.  They stared into the glass case with an air of mysteriousness.  Vincent Jefferson smiled.  It was his profession that was causing him such problems...  It was his profession that caused his wife to divorce him and his child to be left in someone else's hands.  It was his profession that caused such trouble, yet it was his profession that kept his child support paid.  Vincent Jefferson noticed the irony of his situation, and let out a short laugh.</lj-cut>
