"So we should be moving... yes?"

Arthur was about to make a transition to another room when a housemaid approached him and whispered something into his ear.

"What are you talking about?" he demanded.

"Well, I don't know, but the painting's-"

The maid had no time to complete her thought as Arthur rushed downstairs and everyone followed him.  Arthur shoved the butler aside and thrust the doors open to the music room.

"What's the meaning of this?!" demanded Arthur as he turned to the butler, who was just recovering from his fall when Arthur grabbed him from the collar.  "What the hell happened here?!"

"I don't know sir," said the butler with as much dignity as he could muster, which wasn't much at all.  Arthur dropped him to the ground as he straightened his collar.

By this time, everyone had entered the room and stood with an expression of shock.  Everyone was staring at a fifteen by twenty foot blank wall where the Arsene Lupin painting once stood.  Disbelief spread throughout the whole room, but the impossible was true!  Arsene Lupin had vanished!</lj-cut>

<lj-cut>"If it isn't Detective West Courier!"

"Angela!"

The three had arrived to the yacht.  It was still raining, though not as badly as before.  Unfortunately for James, his cold wasn't showing signs of letting up any time soon.

"James, I remember you, too!"

Angela Lightfoot was an old friend of West Courier.  The two had met in college and had run into each other in the occasional coffee shop at least once a week.  Angela was a very beautiful woman, in fact.  Her beautiful blonde hair flowed down her sides and back.  She normally wore slightly more clothes in the form of shorts and a short T-shirt, but today she was in a raincoat, and even at her age, she was a damn beautiful sight to behold, or so West Courier thought.  He didn't however, have quite the right mind to marry her, partially because she was already married herself, though other guys at the coffee shot always tended to forget between her beautiful blue eyes and blonde hair.

West Courier, on the other hand, was an interesting contrast.  He was in his middle-ages like her, only he had a permanent five o'clock shadow and a dark face that suggested being out in the sun for a long time, yet not quite sunburned.  Everywhere he went, West had a hat on, and so when he took it off, it was natural that it should be permanently messy underneath.  Today, he was sporting a sweater and baseball cap.  The perfect clothing for rainy weather.  His dark hair and dark eyes shone underneath that cap and had a strange light to them, creating a strange contrast to the rest of his face.

"So we're the first one here?" West assumed.  James let out a sneeze and Angela let out a laugh.

"Actually, you happen to be the last ones here," she giggled.  Angela led the way as West and James boarded the yacht.

"Small party, huh?" West asked as he noticed four others being the only ones on the ship.  It wasn't large enough to accomodate as much as an ocean liner at all, so naturally James looked inquisitively to his uncle.

"Were can we throw our stuff at?" asked West as he waved to the other four.

"Over here," Angela said, directing West and James downstairs into the boat.  The layout of the boat was as follows:

---
Kitchen || West's Room | James's Room || Vic's Room | Madison's Room
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Stairs | HALLWAY
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Dining || Angela's Room | Bill's Room || Lance's Room | Shin'ichi's Room
---

So upon entering the yacht, West, James, and Angela passed by the kitchen and dining rooms and took a left into West Courier's room, where half of the luggage was dropped off.  The three then went into James's room to drop off the other half of the luggage, as well as the dog cage.  Bullet was let loose then, and darted like a madman up the stairs to enjoy the rain.

"It's a little late to ask if that was okay," muttered West under his breath.  Angela only let out a slightly seductive smile.

"Maybe I should introduce you to everyone else on the yacht?" she asked.  West agreed to it, but James used his nose as an excuse to stay in his room.  The two went up to the deck, as James stood in his room.

It was a fair room.  There was a bed and a restroom that he shared with his uncle.  There was a separate door that opened to his uncle's wood.  It seemed as if the entire room was made of wood.  The floor, wood, and ceiling all shone a dull brown, though James could tell that it was well taken care of, due to the visible water droplets on the ground from tracking footprints.

"Wax has been newly applied, else the water would have gotten into the wood," James observed to himself.  He smiled.  He was sick, but he still had his mental capacities intact.

James walked around to the other rooms, taking a peek inside.  He walked across the hallway to Angela's room, then to Bill's room, then Lance's room, and noticed that they were all basically set up the same way as his own room, even with the fresh water droplets on the ground and the packed luggage.  Evidently, the guests hadn't bothered to open up their luggage, and preferred to look on deck for the final passengers who had arrived about five minutes ago now.  James also noted the adjacent rooms between Angela and Bill, and Lance and Shin'ichi.  Of course, James hadn't known these names without any clues; signs on the doors made it all too obvious.

James had also checked on Vic's and Madison's rooms to find they were the same.  He finally made his way to Shin'ichi's room.  Turning the handle, he found its occupant still inside!

"Ah!" said James, taken aback.  He thought it strange that the room's occupant happened to be no older than seven years old.  The kid pushed his glasses up and let out a short chuckle.  He was dressed rather oddly in blue shorts and a blue tuxedo coat, under which a boetie was present.  The kid was, evidently, the only one caring to unpack his clothes before looking around the yacht.

"Sorry!" James exclaimed.  He noticed the kid's eyes darting very quickly around the room before giving a proper response.

"That's okay!" he said with a big smile.  James couldn't see his eyes, but there was something... unnatural about them... even if they were just the normal shade of brown.

"My name's James Hamish," James said sheepishly, holding out his hand.

"I'm Shin'ichi!  Shin'ichi Cohen!" the boy said.  "You know, it's a good thing you took a shower after running this morning, or you might be all smelly!  Of course, you shouldn't have been running in the rain in the first place, which is why you have that cold!"

"Ahahaha!" James laughed.  "I suppose I shouldn't...!?"

James stopped and his face grew suddenly serious.  How did he......?

Shin'ichi smiled and handed James a tissue.

"It's simple!" Shin'ichi explained, after studying James's face.  "The back of your shoes have mud on them, so you obviously must have been running, and running this morning, because that was the only time you could get mud on your shoes and have the mud still on right now.  Also, there's no mud tracking on the bottom of your shoes, so you must have gone back indoors with a lot of time to spare before leaving to come here.  I noticed that you backed away from the door quickly when you saw someone was in my room, so you had to have some kind of courtesy, especially with how fast you apologized!  It would only make sense that you would have had enough courtesy to take a shower before you came here!  And I knew you had a cold because... well... you were sneezing!"

Shin'ichi stood with that cryptic smile on his face that James started to grow amazed and scared of.  He'd hardly seen the kid for ten seconds and already he was able to deduce all that!

"How.... how did you know all that... so quickly?" said James in slight amazement.

"Well, it just makes sense!" said Shin'ichi.

"Hah!  Well, you ARE a strange kid, I suppose," said James noting his odd dress and lack of books and video games.  "I suppose you've come here with family because you were forced to."

"Well, I did come here with family," admitted Shin'ichi, "but not because I was forced to..."

"In that case," said James, "you came to... study people?"

Shin'ichi nodded and pushed his glasses up.

"It's too bad," said Shin'ichi, "that no one else unpacked their stuff.  Otherwise we might be able to learn more about them, too!"

James smiled back at the kid as he rushed out the door to the deck.

"What a strange kid," James repeated to himself.</lj-cut>

<lj-cut>Martin followed Dr. Hadean and Arthur out the library.  Arthur returned to the dining room where guests were drinking wine and whatnot and announced that it was time for the "grand tour".

We were a few dozen people in all, though many people weren't exactly interesting to Martin.  He noted the jewelry flashing around their arms and necks, the husbands flirting and the wives chirping, and almost all of whom were talking about how much their new yachts cost or how much their diamond ring was.  Martin looked at his right hand where his wedding ring rested.  It used to be a dazzling ornament of gold.  Simple yet amazing.  But now, it was growing dull, and the luster had left long ago.

Martin spied one female in particular who caught his attention.  She dressed more conservatively than the others and had nothing shining on her save her two diamond earrings.  Her necklace was a dull gold that would have matched perfectly with Martin's ring.

The lady caught Martin staring at her and blushed slightly.  Her face was just as beautiful red as it was in its normal shade of white.  She wore makeup, sure, but not so much as to look like a clown.  She kept her hair tied in a bun, and it gave her the appearance of the typical secretary.

"I'm sorry..." Martin said sheepishly.

"Oh, I..."  She held out her hand and offered her name.  "My name is Bethany Shadows."

Martin grasped it firmly and offered his own to her.  "Martin Pershing."

"So what do you do?" asked Bethany.

The conversation continued as the two passed various rooms which, though impressive from the inside, added absolutely nothing to the house except as a storage for fancy vases and pictures and the like.

Eventually, they reached the music room.  The room was located in a corner of the house and, as if the shining black grand piano in the center of the room didn't say enough, there were imported red drapes hanging over the windows, more vases that held no flowers, and...

"The painting of Arsene Lupin!"

Arthur announced it in his usual voice and over-pronounced the nasal parts of the French name.  The painting was, of course, beautiful, and everyone stood in awe.

Martin and Bethany were standing together by a window.  Bethany wasn't exactly excited by the picture, but gave it her attention.

"Is this the picture," Martin asked aloud, "that that man Vincent Jefferson proposed to steal?"

The room was quickly silenced by this question as everyone quickly recalled the message that Dr. Hadean had apparently shown everyone.  A few people let out laughs including a man who appeared borderline drunk.

"Well, if that idiot Vinshent Jeffershon thinksh he c'n shteal thish painching," said the bloated man through his moustaches, "then let him try!  There ain' no way shomeone can carry thish thing outta here wishout bein' notished!"  The man's wife then apologized for her husband, Kerry Manfred, acting as he did, and told him that she wished that he wouldn't act so.

"I c'n act any way I wanner, Josie!" Kerry shouted.  Josephine was her true name, and she looked very ashamed at this remark.  Her wavy hair seemed to grow untidy the angrier she got with him.  Josephine pulled on Kerry's ear and, holding the ear in one hand and her dress in the other, made her way to another room to yell at him.

Indeed, it was true, for the painting stood at least 15 feet by 20 feet, and it would be no easy task fitting it through the window Martin happened to be looking out of, much less carrying it right out of the party through the front doors without someone noticing.

Martin had reverted his gaze to the window, for he thought he noticed something move...

"Did you see that?" he asked, shaking Bethany's shoulder.  She turned her head outside and told him she didn't see anything.

"I could have sworn someone was outside..." Martin explained.  He searched the window for a little longer, then shrugged his shoulders, blaming it on the wind.

"In any case!" said Arthur Chester, regaining control of his crowd, "It will be impossible for him to enter and leave the place undetected!  For you see, the painting will not fit through any window, and will only fit through the door you just entered.  However!  The door, as you have noticed, is guarded by one of my butlers, a Mr. Stiles and a most respected man who has worked for me for many years!  Mr. Stiles is perfectly capable of seeing someone carrying a 15 by 20 foot canvas outside of the room, and so it is impossible for the painting to be stolen!"

There was some applause from the group.  Bethany and Martin clapped their hands as well, as Josephine and Kerry returned.  Arthur Chester was about to continue his tour of the place when a butler walked into the room with something rather large and rectangular shaped wrapped in brown paper.

"Where shall I put this, sir?" the butler asked, sweating.

"You should leave it here!" announced Arthur Chester, "and I should open it when the guests are gone, so as not to disturb them."

The room was about as big as a small house anyway, so there was no trouble fitting such a big package into the room with the grand piano and the dozens of guests occupying it as well.

"But don't you believe," Bethany asked Martin at length, "that the painting might sooner or later be stolen?  After all, he is the great Vincent Jefferson."

"Vincent Jefferson," said Dr. Hadean, entering the conversation without warning, "is just a man.  He won't be able to remove the painting from this house without passing through that door.  He can't make paintings vanish into thin air!  He will have to abide by the laws of physics, and if he tries to steal from this house tonight, he will also have to abide by the laws of the state."  Dr. Hadean had been studying the crowd closely while he said this to Bethany and Martin and remarked, "Though I would keep an eye on that Skip Carter.  His name and person suggest something.... strange..."  And he left the two to study more about Skip Carter.

Skip Carter stood admiring not the picture, rather, the piano in the room.  His hair was sleek and stayed in place.  His hands looked rough, as well as his shoes, and he had eyes that were almost as shifty as the detective's, though the color of them suggested a kind of evil behind them.  Besides that, he had the wonderful facade of being pleasant toward every other guest.

"We should continue our tour, though," said Arthur Chester, as he led everyone out the door.

As the guests were leaving, Martin began kneeling onto the ground and pressing the red carpet for something.

"What are you looking for?" asked Bethany.

"It's just my ring," said Martin.  "I'll be fine looking for it alone.  It can't have gone far."

"I'll see you later on the tour then?" asked Bethany.  Martin smiled and nodded, and he was left alone to look for his ring, for he had been fidgeting with it while staring at Bethany, wondering what it was like to be married... to be in love...  Wondering why that one thing would have separated himself from his former wife...</lj-cut>

<lj-cut>It was the last day before the cruise.  The last day of freedom.  The last day a teenager could really run free before being locked up and stored away in a ship for a week.

It was raining outside.  Not exactly ideal conditions to be practicing parkour, but James Hamish figured it would help his balance.  He'd become fairly skilled in the rain; the last time he twisted his ankle was months ago, and it had fully healed.

James ran in sweats and a T-shirt.  His ideal training clothes.  From first glance, one might be led to believe that James was actually running just like everyone else in the morning, the only difference being that he was running unusually earlier than anyone else.  Four o'clock to be exact.  James was sure that he wouldn't therefore attract the attention of little kids and cops.  It was just the right time so there would be no drunk drivers for cops to watch out for, and too early for parents to be worried about their kids copying that "irresponsible teenager."

It was true, he had badly damaged his right leg while practicing once, which explained his natural limp.  His uncle, Detective West Courier (a man blessed with two last names), was surely surprised to find his nephew limping back to his door with a broken leg, and even moreso when he found out that he had broken his leg out "jogging".

In any case, that was years ago, and he was much more skilled now, as he easily cleared a five-foot wall and landed in someone's back yard.  That was another advantage at being up at four o'clock.  People were rarely up at that time, and even if they were up, they'd be too dazed to get a good look at anyone in their yard and might dismiss it as having been a memory from a dream.

James kicked off a wall to scale an eight footer.  He himself was nearing six feet in height, and by standing on tip-toes alone could not have easily climbed over the wall.

"It should be useful," James thought to himself when he first started the "sport".  "It should be useful, though I have no idea what for."

James was back on a sidewalk after venturing through a few more back yards.  He checked his watch.  It was digital and he never wore it except for training, because he didn't like how it looked.  His dark brown hair bobbed against his head as he continued jogging and checking his watch.  Four-thirty.  He had to shower and such before it was time to leave for the cruise.  James took a right and scaled another wall, walking along the top of it until he came back into his own back yard.  He jumped the gate to get into the front yard and entered his home like a proper gentleman, soaked with a disgusting mixture of sweat and rainwater.  His outdoor sneakers were lined with mud and dog feces.  He smelled as nice as his uncle's breath, as his uncle had not yet brushed his teeth.

"Break anything?" his uncle asked, staring at the morning newspaper.  The wet casing lay on the table.  It was the weather page today, as if his uncle couldn't tell what the weather was like outside.

"You shouldn't run in the rain.  You might catch a cold," his uncle told him.

"That hasn't been scientifically proven," said James as he removed his once-white shoes.  He wiped the water off of his face to find that the gesture had only succeeded in making his face wetter.

"I'm taking a shower," James reported.  His uncle, West Courier, nodded and sipped some black coffee, that had effectively stained his teeth over the years, though he managed to hide it with teeth-whitening kits.  He and James had gotten into an argument about whether coffee or tea was better.  West sided with coffee.

"I packed your stuff already," West barked to James.

"Thanks, dad."

The door shut.  The sound of the shower was audible throughout the quiet and dark household.  Bullet, James's dog, had just awaken and rushed downstairs to give West Courier the usual greetings, characterized by jumping on the table, slipping on the wet cloth, and giving West's face various licks until West placed Bullet back on the ground.  West took a cup of water and walked outside.  About a minute later, he filled Bullet's bowl with fresh rainwater.  Bullet showed his eternal gratefulness by running outside and gathering the water on his coat before West chased him back into the house.  The cage was set next to the luggage, all of which was to the side of the front door and ready to depart.  Bullet was evidently coming to the cruise as well.

West seemed satisfied with his paper and folded it back up.  James rushed downstairs, having finished his shower, and hugged Bullet.  The little beagle was happy to see anyone and everyone, and would therefore find himself at home on the cruise.

"Ready?" West asked.

James grabbed a banana and devoured it quickly.  He nodded after a short fifteen second interval consisting of digestion.

"Let's go."

West grabbed the rest of the luggage and piled it into the car.  James let Bullet into the cage.  As West went to lock the door, James let out a sneeze.  Bullet barked, and West said with an air of triumph, "I told you so."</lj-cut>

<lj-cut>It was that time of the month again.  Time to pay the child support, and, as usual, Martin Pershing was having a hard time finding the money to pay for it.  Of course, he would have to resort to his last resort once again.

It was years since Martin Pershing had divorced his wife, but not soon enough to avoid having a child.  The divorce was made for one of the strangest of reasons, though it made perfect sense.  After all, Martin Pershing and his wife were absolutely compatible in every way imaginable.  They loved the same movies, the same food... they always did nice things for each other, held doors open, pulled out chairs, had a little fun...  Yet it was one simple reason that the wife decided to break away from Martin's wife.

Martin looked at himself in the mirror.  He had hardly recognized his figure.  He stared at a middle-aged man.  A balding middle-aged man at that, though a stylish hat would easily cover that up.  He was still in shape, and was grateful for his health, though.  He still had all his teeth, and they were as pearly as ever.  If he were ten or twenty years younger, he wouldn't be able to walk out in public without girls from all directions mauling him.  

But perhaps his most mysterious feature was his grey eyes.  No one had eyes quite like them.  The eyes caught everything, but were very secretive about it.  They were quite mysterious in that they told nothing about the man to those who knew nothing about him, yet everything about the man who truly knew him.  Martin placed some eye contacts in and blinked furiously until the contacts found their place in his eyes, darkening the grey and producing a natural brown.

Martin knew he could get his money soon, and therefore he was not distressed at all in attending a friend's party.  After checking to see if he looked his finest in his dark suit, Martin left his apartment.

---

It was a gaudy mansion of three stories, and it almost hurt one's eyes as they strained to see the entire mass of the building at once.  It was a typical dream mansion with windows staring outside every room and light emitting from all rooms as well.  If the outside was gaudy, however, the inside was just disgusting.  Chandeliers hung from every ceiling and lit up the room as if the sun never went down.  It was all so beautiful with the perfectly polished wooden doors and the rugs from all over the world spread on top of the perfectly polished wooden floor.  There was not a speck of dust out of place, and Martin noted all of this as he took his first few steps into the abode of Sir Arthur Jeiger Candide Frankstein Chester III, esq., or Arthur as he demanded everyone call him, except his various housemaids and servants who had to refer to him by Mr. Chester.

"Gaudy," Martin muttered under his breath.

"You like it?" Arthur asked, as he walked into the foyer and approached the front door.  "The foyer," thought Martin to himself, "must be the most useless room mankind has created."

"It's......" Martin was apparently at a loss for words.

"It's marvellous, isn't it?" asked Arthur in a borderline feminine voice.  He looked borderline feminine himself, with his over-polished shoes, lint-free coat, and glossily moussed brown hair.  Martin almost winced looking at the shiny, almost fake figure standing in front of him.  He smiled and outstretched his hand.

"Come, come, the guests are waiting," said Arthur as he shoved Martin in front of him.

There were guests all right.  Martin hadn't really noticed who any of them were except Arthur's wife, Louisa Chester; and a detective, Dr. Hadean.  Arthur's wife was almost as gaudily dressed as the house.  A glittering dress of jewels draped her body and reflected every light that shone upon them.  Louisa was probably twenty, and was obviously far too young for Arthur.  Her dark brown hair flowed down her Russian body.  Diamond necklaces lined her neck and golden bracelets covered her arms so the perfect skin underneath might be preserved.  She was almost fake, thought Martin to himself.

Dr. Hadean, on the other hand, was dressed in a dirty suit and wore a ruffled moustache.  His hair was hastily brushed for the occasion, and it showed.  Dr. Hadean's eyes darted left and right quickly to evidently collect suspicious activity, though Martin saw none to detect.

"Ladies and gentlement," Arthur anounced in a projected, feminine voice.  "May I present to you my friend Martin Pershing."

It was as if applause should be heard at that point.  Martin felt awkward, as he didn't know whether or not to bow or walk away shamefully for a lack of applause, though evidently none was to be expected, as the others resumed their talk.  Louisa approached them, and after a long and unnecessary embracement with her supposedly legally married husband, who, with no doubt, had already married many women of tewnty before and would marry many women of twenty after having finished with Louisa, shook hands with Martin.

"Pleasure," blurted out Martin.

"Oh, the pleasure's all mine," said Louisa with as much sex as she could put into her words

"Might I ask," said Martin as he turned to Arthur, "why the good Detective Hadean is here?"

"Everyone's been asking us all night," remarked Louisa.  "It is rather annoying that he should get more questioning than me," she said out of jealousy.

"It's an interesting story, really," said Arthur, ignoring his wife.  "I suppose you might have him come over and he should tell you himself.  Oh, Dr. Hadean!"

Dr. Hadean looked up from his observations and walked over to Arthur.  Dr. Hadean happened to be wearing boots to the occasion, which clunked everywhere he happened to walk.

"Dr. Hadean, I believe you should have the honors of telling Martin why you are here."

"Right," said Dr. Hadean after studying Martin carefully.  Dr. Hadean led Martin into a library room that was unusually quieter than the rest of the house.  Dr. Hadean closed the door and looked about the bookshelves to be sure that no one was there before he began his explanation.

"You see, actually, the Chesters have received a.. well... a message.  A kind of threat..."

Dr. Hadean studied his reactions carefully, but Martin had little.  Death was the first thing that crossed his mind, though the second thing was easily theft.

"It is a threat of... well, perhaps you should read it yourself."

Dr. Hadean produced an envelope from his inside sleeve and handed it to Martin.  He unfolded the envelope and the message inside.  The message was a letter addressed to Arthur and Louisa and read as follows:

---
Dearest Sir Arthur Jeiger Candide Frankstein Chester III, esq. and Louisa Chester:
I have come to acquire your most valued treasure, that is, that prized painting of Arsene Lupin.  I shall arrive at the Thirtieth of July to retrieve it, unless you feel at liberty to deliver it to me.

Faithfully Yours,
Vincent Jefferson
---

It was the well-known thief Vincent Jefferson!  Martin recalled the date as being July 30!  What an excitement the party now appeared to be after the revelation of a possible thief among the party guests!

"And have you caught him yet?" Martin asked.

Dr. Hadean gave him a cold glance that told him that Vincent Jefferson was, evidently, still at large.

"That is all you need to know," said Dr. Hadean as he took the envelope and message back.

"Excuse me, sirs!" said Arthur as he came bounding into the room as if skipping through a field of flowers and daffodils.  "We are about to display the fabulous painting of Arsene Lupin!  Won't you join us?"

And the three left the library room to see the painting that this Vincent Jefferson proposed to steal.</lj-cut>

The fact that the announcement came only yesterday led me to believe that it wasn't a bomb, because bombs take quite a bit of preparation.  So what else could possibly be smoke?  Smoke bombs?  A simple prank.  I figured I'd be more prepared for something more drastic."

<lj-cut>"Vince!"

During all the confusion, Vince had finally come out of wherever he was, and Alia found him.  They were outside and away from the now smoky auditorium.

<lj-cut>Kelly Stockton had evidently forgotten that she was at the interrogation booth instead of the forensics booth.  Her glasses to detect luminol were still on her face, and she had the bottle of luminol on the table.  Her hair was tied back as usual in case she had the chance to investigate a murder case.  Clearly, this was her lucky day.

"Besides from being on the CSI team, how do you know Danielle?" James asked.

Kelly was a junior, and therefore didn't really know Danielle very well.

"But I did know her through orchestra?"

"Orchestra?"

"Yeah, Dani and I played in the city youth orchestra!  We were both strings.  It's not like school orchestras where the strings get all of the melodies, though.  The strings are usually the background.

"Actually, Dani and I sat right next to each other!  I was 32nd chair and she was 31st.  I didn't really talk to her much after that incident..."

"That incident?" James pressed.

"Well, I happen to have the best violin in orchestra," Kelly bragged.  "It cost a lot of money.  That, and the bow was perfectly made and everything.  I don't know if you know a lot about violins, but it's not all about the strings themselves.  A lot of it has to do with the bow, how light it is, and how the hairs touch the strings.  And mine was definitely the best.

"One day, I left my violin on my chair to go to the... ladies' room.  After class, my friend Toby told me that Dani switched bows with me.  Of course, he didn't have to tell me.  That bow didn't feel perfect at all.  It's no wonder she switched bows with that trash she was using...

"I talked to Dani about it the next day, but she didn't say anything.  So we stopped talking."

"How much did the bow cost?" asked James.

Kelly seemed reluctant to admit that it was probably worth as much as a used car, and a good-conditioned used car at that.

---

Kelly had left the booth already and James asked me to check the progress on the poison analysis.

"Especially that one ingredient," he hinted.

I knew which one he was talking about, but when I checked over the analysis, I found it strange that it didn't have substantially more poison than the other ingredients...

"Pepperoni was about the same as the mushroom and olives.  Cheese was about the same, too," I reported.

"And the green peppers?" James asked excitedly.

I frowned.  "Just the same as the other ingredients..."

"Damn."

James shut his eyes and started humming to himself.  It was an odd habit he had when he was thinking about something complicated, like his English essays.

"It looks like it could only have been done by two people," James said.

I nodded in agreement.

"But that would be dangerous..." James muttered.

---

Five minutes of humming continued until James stopped and opened his eyes.

"It would be dangerous..." he repeated to himself.

"Hey, I want you to check everyone else's drinks for any kind of... peculiarity..." James trailed off.

I was about to leave when he yelled, "By the way, bring Louis over here..."

---

I had the CSI team analyze the drinks just as James asked, though we found nothing.  Maybe because we had no idea what we were looking for.  James tended to do that.  He would ask people to do something without telling them why he wanted the people to do what he asked them to do.  It was annoying, especially when you were the one taking orders from him.

I arrived back at the table to tell him what we found (or didn't find, in this case).  James was still questioning Louis, who looked fairly angry by that time.

"She was always screwing with my science experiments and with everything else!" Louis said loudly.  "She would always do stupid things like throw my backpack in the trash or stick a cockroach in it or something!  It was so disgusting!!"

James looked as if he was about to laugh.

"And that's why you hated her?"

"Well, yes!  Wouldn't you hate a girl so annoying as that?!"

Of course, Louis was the "prim and proper" kind of person.  Everything was always neat and organized with him, and if it wasn't, he'd nearly die.  But I hardly believed someone would kill over that.

Louis stood up before James could finish his questioning.  James didn't pursue him any further.  I approached the table and sat opposite of James.

"Well, I think he has a form of OCD, though I'm no psychologist myself," remarked James.  "He seems mentally ill, though I doubt that would drive him to kill Danielle...  By the way, do you happen to have the results from the tests I asked you to run?"

"Well," I started, "I didn't find anything... unusual... though I had no idea what you wanted me to find..."

James looked disappointed.

"You would have known if it was there," he responded.  "So the drinks were all normal?"

I nodded.

"Well, that eliminates our other two suspects, and now we're at... how many?" James asked sarcastically.

"Going off of what you said earlier - that it could only have been two people - we have... no possible suspects."

"Perfect," said James.  "I wanted to eliminate just one, and now I eliminated the two of them...

"You sat next to Danielle, right?" James asked.  I nodded.  He had sat across from Danielle.  Between the two of us, there was no way anyone could slip poison at the table without our knowing..."

He was waiting for me to suggest that someone had hovered their hand over Danielle's food.  I shook my head.

"You sure you didn't poison her?" James asked, jokingly.  I shook my fist at him.

Of course, looking at the evidence, that was the only possibility.  Unless it was just a random act...</lj-cut>

<lj-cut>"Wait a sec.  You're seriously questioning me?"

Coach Darrell had the usual smile on his face, though right now it seemed to be saying, "You guys must be out of your minds."  James and I sat on the receiving end of that smile.  I didn't know what to say, but fortunately James was the one in charge of all of this questioning.

"Coach, I'm just looking for the whole truth."

James looked very formal, almost like a businessman ready to engage in a hostile takeover.  Coach Darrell talked down to him like he was a little boy trying to sell lemonade or something.

"Go ahead and ask me, then," Coach said.

"Did you happen to have any problems with Danielle?  Any fights or arguments or something?"

Coach Darrell laughed again.  It sounded phonier by the second, and James stared straight at him.  He was seeing something I wasn't, I think.

"Well, you know kids and teachers... there's going to be some arguments sometimes."

Coach ran a dark-skinned hand over his bald head and James nodded.  I noted that Coach kept his other hand down by his side...

"Well, did she ever get you in trouble for something at school?"

Coach looked to the table and James's eyes definitely caught it.

"No, she did not," he replied.

"So you never had any real problems with Danielle, correct?"

"I did not."  Coach straightened himself in his seat and looked ready to get back to the forensics.  Quite frankly, I wanted to get back over there as well, but James really wanted me around.

Coach stood up.  James shoved me out of the way and held out his hand to shake.

Coach gave him an odd smile and held out his right hand to catch James's... left.

"You're doing it backwards," James remarked.  "I'm holding out my left hand.  Won't you meet it with yours?"

Coach hesitated for a moment, then held out his other hand.  A large bandage was wrapped around it, rendering his left hand almost immobile.  They shook hands and before Coach Darrell could leave, James asked, "Where'd you get it from?"

"Cooking," Coach grunted.  "I gotta get back to work."

---

"Hello, Shandra," James said warmly.

Shandra nodded and inspected the booth opposite us before sitting down.

"How well did you know Danielle?" James asked.

"Well, we ate lunch together every day.  I didn't know her very well, though, because we had a large group of people eating together with us at lunch..."

"Did you ever get into a fight with Danielle?"

Obviously not, and I could have answered that.  Shandra was just far too quiet and avoided confrontation.

"No...  I mean, the closest thing we got to fighting was..."

James waited.  Shandra was reshaping her mouth into different vowels, apparently hoping to find the right word.

"Well, she did make fun of me a few times, but it wasn't really...  It wasn't really mean or anything."

James had a reassuring smile on his face.

"Do you know why anyone else would want to kill her?" asked James.

Shandra shook her head.  James nodded and told her that she could return.  James's eyes followed her closely as she turned her back and walked away...

"Chris?"

"Yeah?"

James was staring at the forensics booth and apparently wanted more information from there.

"I'm gonna take a bathroom break."

Apparently not.

"But what I want you to do is find out more about that poison that killed Danielle."

James left and I walked over to the forensics table...

---

Five minutes passed before I returned.  James (thank God) was already out of the bathroom before then.

"What's up?" he asked.

"It seems like there was a heck of a lot of poison there.  We tested a lot of things so far - the crust, the mushrooms, olives, sauce...  We haven't tested the green peppers, pepperoni, or cheese yet, but from what we've found so far, there's poison on every one of these.  Also, it seems less apparent in the crust and sauce, but it's definitely there..."

"Seems like someone wanted to make sure she was really going to die...  What'd you say the ingredients of the pizza were?"

"Crust, mushrooms, olives, sauce, green peppers, pepperoni, cheese."

James wrote down what everyone else had ordered and came up with the following (unorganized) list:

---

Me: Crust, Pepperoni, Cheese, Sauce
Chris: Crust, Cheese, Sauce
Elias: Crust, Cheese, Sauce, Pepperoni, Anchovies
Shandra: Crust, Cheese, Sauce, Pepperoni, Sausage
Kelly: Crust, Cheese, Sauce, Mushroom, Olives
Lewis (that was misspelled on the paper, by the way): Crust, Cheese, Sauce, Pepperoni, Olives
Darrell: Crust, Cheese, Sauce
Danielle (Victim): Crust*1, Mushrooms*2, Olives*2, Sauce*1, Green Peppers, Pepperoni, Cheese

---

"What are the asterisks for?" I asked, stumbling on the word "asterisk".

"That's what you've already tested.  On a scale of most poisonous to least, two being the most poisonous, I've marked the ingredients..."

I looked over the list and was about to sit back down again when James asked me, "By the way, you mind bringing Kelly here?"</lj-cut>

<lj-cut>"Don't touch that..."

Everyone was surrounding the body and was about to alter the crime scene until James spoke up.

"I thought that would be obvious.  The first thing you do is not touch the crime scene."

He looked at me, and I understood to call the police.

---

It was a few minutes of talking on my cell phone until I got back to James.  He was busy making sure no one would touch the crime scene.

"I just called the police, James.  They told me that they wouldn't be able to have anyone come down until about an hour or two.  The police are really busy tonight with other crimes..."

It was a very lame excuse, but it was the one they gave me in the first place.  James was, of course, irritated by this... or so I expected.

He cracked his knuckles and a smile grew on his face.

"Guess this one's up to us, huh, Chris?"

---

We set up an interrogation booth and a lab processing booth in the restaurant.  We happened to have been sitting in a corner of the restaurant for our banquet when Danielle died, so it was fairly easy to keep track of the crime scene.  The lab processing booth was in another corner of the restaurant.  James and I sat in the interrogation booth, which was located in the third corner of the restaurant.  We were able to keep an eye on the other corners from where we were sitting.

"The main suspects are the server, Joan Keller; and the cook Fabian Gullian.  Of course, Elias, Shandra, Kelly, Louis, and Coach Darrell are suspects..." James trailed off.

"If that were so, you and I would be suspects too, right?"

James gave me a strange look.

---

"You are Joan Keller, correct?"

Joan was about the same age as the rest of us.  She had her hair tied up in a bun and no necklaces or other loose chains.  It was the typical waitress look.

"Yes."

"Tell me everything you know about Danielle Glover."

"The dead girl, right?"

It wasn't exactly eloquent, the way she put it, but James didn't seem to notice.

"Well, I don't know her very well," Joan started.  "I mean, I only know her because she used to work here.  She worked here last year, that is..."

"How long did she work here?" asked James.

"Well... about a half a year.  I was working here before she got a job."

"I think a half a year is a long enough time to know someone, Joan."

"Well, yes."

James watched her eyes closely.  Her eyes watched the table closely.  I looked toward the forensics table and felt that I belonged over there instead.  I didn't exactly care too much for interrogation...

"Are you hiding something, Joan?"

James's face was still rather warm.  Not like that of a cross-examiner or an interrogator, rather like a friend waiting for juicy gossip.  Joan bought in.

"Actually..." her face still looked down at the table.  James wasn't pressing even after the rather long silence.

"Actually, I know that she used to flirt with some of the guys here...  I mean, she'd come on to them, and when they finally started coming on to her too..."

She looked up and smiled as if she had been relieved of a much bigger secret than that.

"And that's all I basically know about her!"

"Do you know why anyone would want to kill Danielle?" James asked.

Joan shook her head.  I thought James would have asked her more questions, but instead he gave her a warm smile and told her that she could ask the cook to come.

---

I looked over to the forensics booth as James started questioning Fabian Gullian.  He was the eldest one here, and it seemed odd that a teenager should question someone as old as he.

"Kid, are you seriously going to question me?"  He looked irritated.

James took the same demeanor as before, though.

"Do you know why anyone would want to kill Danielle?"

"Dude, I don't see much of Danielle, ok?  I just hang out in the kitchen and make the food."

The man was fat and his stains on his apron looked more like blood and sweat instead of the pizza sauce that it really was.

"But that wasn't my question."

James's face changed.  He leaned forward in the seat.  It was as if he was manipulating the shadows so only his eyes could clearly be seen in the poor lighting that was the pizza parlor.

"Do you know why anyone would want to kill Danielle?"

Fabian leaned closer to James as well and spoke in a very low voice.

"I know that she sometimes took food and money that wasn't hers, but I really don't know what you're talking about."

James managed a smirk.

"Your pizza sucks, by the way."

Fabian the cook's face grew uglier and he spit on the table right in front of James.

"Don't be insulting my pizza."

He stood up and walked off.  James looked satisfied.  I was bored.

"Hey, Chris."

I looked over and he motioned toward the forensics booth.

"Why don't you send Elias over here?  Also, I want you to tell me what's going on at that forensics booth."

I was happy to be relieved of listening to interrogations and actually doing something.

---

I returned to the interrogation booth in the middle of James's questioning of Elias.

"She was having a fight with Shandra?"

James's eyes were lit up as Elias spoke.

"Yeah, yeah!  It was really scary, now that I think of it, but it was still exciting at the time!  I don't remember what they were arguing about, but I remember that they were in a hallway, and they were yelling about something... I think they were arguing over something stupid like arguing over a boy.  That's what girls tend to do anyways, argue over boys.  I mean..."

Elias was about a million miles per hour when he spoke.

"Did anyone else have problems with Danielle?"

"Well, I remember Coach Darrell talking really serious to her and stuff.  I mean, it was after we had a meeting one day, and I decided to stick around and test more stuff with luminol.  I heard Coach and Danielle yelling at each other, and I got kinda scared there, too, so I left the room, and I went back in when Danielle left.  I didn't see Coach around, so I asked where he was, but he told me he would be all right and that he was closing up his classroom soon.  I decided to spray a bit more luminol, and when I sprayed luminol on his table, I noticed... guess what... guess what I noticed!"

"Blood?" James asked, apparently excited.

"Yeah!  I found blood on his desk!  I don't know whose blood it was, but I know that it was right where Danielle and Coach were talking.  I also noticed that the next day, Coach had his arm in a big bandage.  It was really weird because Coach wasn't walking around with a bandage the day before, but he was walking around with it then!  You know what that means?!  It means that Danielle cut his arm!"

It made the most sense, actually.  I made a mental note to check Danielle's belongings for a knife or something of the like.

James dismissed Elias and turned to me.

"What'd you find?" he asked.

"So far, they've analyzed the drink and the food.  The poison was definitely in the food."

James looked a little disturbed by this.

"That's odd...  It would usually be easier to put the poison in the drink..."

James didn't think too hard on this and asked me to bring the next person - Coach Darrell.</lj-cut>

<lj-cut>The CSI team at our school wasn't exactly a hot topic.  More people were interested in committing crimes rather than solving them.  Luckily, we had a team of seven which allowed us to compete in state.

Unfortunately, we didn't fare well at state.  We were definitely a good team, but we just weren't good enough to analyze the evidence properly, even if James knew what happened all along.

But it was still a fun group.

---

The banquet was to be held at a pizza parlor that was probably named after an Italian.  Revolia's Pizza or something like that.  Two pizzas for seven teenagers and a grown man.  It was going to be gone before I could get a second slice, and judging by how late I was running, it might be gone before I could get my first.

"Hey, Chris!"

Coach Darrell waved to me.  He was a large dark-skinned man who could very well pass for law enforcement.

I waved back and looked around the table.

James Hamish was a rather boring looking guy, actually.  Plain brown hair and brown eyes.  No glasses.  No magnifying glass.  No luminol.  If you passed by him on the street, you wouldn't look back at him and suspect him of being anything special at all.  In fact, his school records reflected just as much; he flunked English sophomore year and had to make it up over the summer.

Elias Nash looked far more exciting.  He was a freshman, and was therefore very immature about anything and everything he did.  His blonde hair matched his annoyingly loud personality, though I suppose he was intelligent at times.

Shandra Blunt was a senior.  She was unusually quiet, but a nice girl once you got to know her.  Her hair was dyed purple.  Probably because she didn't want people to know she was a natural red-head, though I don't understand why she went with purple...

Kelly Stockton had glasses and a pair of shades to go over them.  The shades weren't sunglass shades, however.  They were for the luminol she always carried around with her.  Remember when I talked about those strange forensic fanatics?  She was one of them.

Louis Escher was another fanatic concerning forensics, though not as much so.  He did carry around a magnifying glass and forceps, but he didn't run around with weird forensics books that Kelly did.  Louis was uncannily clean and orderly about everything.  In fact, I might go so far as to say he had OCD, though it did come in handy when analyzing crime scenes.

....There was one person missing, though...

"Glad you could make it, Chris!!"

Elias Nash was very annoying in his high-pitched tenor voice, especially when he was being sarcastic.

"I'm glad you came at all," I fired back.

I took my seat next to Shandra, across from James.

"So what?  Did everyone eat the pizza already and forget to save me a slice?" I asked aloud to no one in particular.

"The pizza hasn't arrived yet."  Shandra looked tired, as usual.

I looked across the table and noticed James looking at another table.  Apparently, someone hadn't cleaned up the table yet, and James looked absolutely fascinated in it.

"What're you looking at, James?" I asked.

James didn't look back at me, but said to the other table, "Tell me how much you know about the couple who sat at that table."

I saw two cups, one with a lid, and one without.  I saw a salt-shaker, two plates, and quite a few unused napkins on top of each.  There were a knife and fork on one plate, and there was ranch by both plates, the one next to the cup with the lid was finished, and the one next to the cup without the lid was untouched.  Also, there was a receipt on the table.

I shrugged.  "There were two people.  They were really neat.  ...I don't see much else..."

"I'll tell you," said James.  "Two people, of course.  No lipstick, so that implies either the people who ate here were both men, or they were both poor.  I don't think they were poor, because I noticed that there was one receipt on the table, and that receipt was for four dollars.  There was no other receipt.  Thus, one person paid for himself, while the other paid for himself as well.  I know the one person paid with credit card because that's the only way to get your receipt here, so the people must not have been poor, and they weren't a couple, or one person would pay for the two of them.  The credit card implies that the two were okay with money, so lipstick would be on the straws if they were women, but there was no lipstick.  Thus, two men, one paying with a credit card.

"I also don't think they're related not only because of the receipt, but also because of the lids.  Notice how only one cup has a lid.  Most people, when living together or related to each other, tend to develop habits similar to one another so they don't realize it.  Thus, no relation.  Probably two men talking over some kind of business.

"The two must have been right-handed because of the position of the cups.  From where each person was sitting, they would have to reach with their right hand to get their cups.  I do know that at least one person was right-handed, however, because the knife and fork are positioned so they are sticking out of the right side of the plate, a place where a right-handed person would usually leave their utensils.

"I finally know that the person who ate the ranch was not only the person who brought the salt, but was also the person who brought both ranch packets.  The two know each other well enough to know that the other likes ranch, but the one person decided not to eat ranch today.  Additionally, the person who ate ranch was the one who got all the supplies, because that person was the only one who ate salt.  I can tell because the salt is closer to that person, and there were no traces of salt detectable on the other plate.

"What do you think about that?"

Shandra looked hardly interested, but I was impressed.

"By the way, where's Danielle?"

"Right here."

While I was listening to James's deduction, Danielle must have slipped into the seat next to me.

Danielle Glover was a senior as well, and wasn't exactly nice, even though she was very smart when it came to processing evidence.  She did have the tendency to rub people the wrong way, if you know what I mean...

The smell of pizza seemed to awaken Shandra.  I was looking for a pie to come to the table, but found it strange that we all ended up with individual slices.  Two each.  I wasn't complaining, but Elias was apparently very hungry as usual and tried to steal Kelly's pizza.  The two were usually roudy, and I had learned to ignore them a long while ago.

"Could you pass me the salt?"

It was an odd habit that Danielle had.  She commonly ate her pizza with salt while other people would put more... normal things like crushed red peppers and the like.  I didn't care, personally.

"Could you pass me the salt when Danielle's done," Shandra asked.

Definitely odd.

---

We had all finished the pizza and Pepsi, and Coach was giving out trophies to the most improved scientist and the most observant scientist and whatnot.  You would think we were some kind of basketball team talking about the best "team player" awards...

"And last, but not least...  The most valuable scientist award goes to...  Danielle Glover!"

We all clapped and looked over to her.  The clapping slowed and eventually ceased to a halt except for Elias and Kelly who were trying to out-clap each other.

There was Danielle, face down on the table.  I checked her pulse...

"So this is what a real crime scene is like..."

Louis had been a little quiet tonight, and I think those were the first words I heard him say.  Elias and Kelly stopped and we were all silent as the other six looked at me to see if there was a pulse.  I dropped my hand and shook my head.</lj-cut>

<lj-cut>Drama.  I hate it.  I didn't assume there would be drama in a forensics club, and it seemed like a fun extra-curricular.  I joined it.  And up until I found out what was really going on in that club, I didn't regret the choice for a single minute.

Not that I was a fanatic about it.  Oh sure, you saw kids running around with luminol and scotch tape to "lift fingerprints" and whatnot.  I wasn't one of them.  James Hamish wasn't either, thankfully.

I wasn't exactly a slack-off, however.  I just happened to be fairly good at working the scenes, but wasn't a fanatic.  I suppose I was a bit of a natural, yet I didn't exactly care too much for the work.  I was more excited watching James tell us all what really happened after we all did the rest of the work.

Speaking of James, he wasn't exactly a hard worker when it came to working the cases.  In fact, I have no idea why he joined at all.  When we were discussing basic techniques, he was hardly around, and when he was, he wasn't paying attention.  He practically hated that club.  But when it came to the actual cases...

But I'm getting off topic.  This story isn't about me or James, it's about the rest of the CSI.  In fact, it's not really about them.  It's about... it's about drama.  It's about how powerful drama can be.  It's about how drama can drive people to do unthinkable things...

My name is Chris Perry.  And this... is my account of... that night...</lj-cut>

<lj-cut>Hector and I were being driven home by Rick.  It was a fairly quiet ride home until...

"What's the difference?"

Hector was riding shotgun and was staring at the dashboard.  Rick and I glanced over in confusion, which I thought was a bad idea for Rick, as he was driving.

"What's the difference between you and a criminal?" Hector asked.

I sat and thought about it for a while and really didn't know...  I mean, we both thought the same way, and we both try to think ahead of each other...

"Idiot!"

Rick hit the steering wheel with his palm.

"The difference between Jim and criminals is that Jimmy here doesn't run around killing people!!"

We laughed, but lying in bed later that night... I thought that might really be the truth.  There was only one difference between criminals and me is that I don't kill people or steal from people or do illegal things.  We both fought for what was right.  The difference was how we fought for it...

I thought about it more, and wondered if Rick really knew what he said...</lj-cut>

<lj-cut>"Hey, Detective Linger..."

We were at the entrance to the arena.  Five minutes before the evidence was processed.  It was now or never...

"Yeah?"

She was already angry from the phone call, so it was no surprise that she sounded like she would kill the first person to give her problems.  Luckily, that person would be me.

"Do you think you could... gather up the suspects and whatnot... and bring them to the crime scene...?"

She looked at me like I was an idiot.

"Why don't you round them up yourself?!"

Unfortunately, she wasn't as cooperative as that other case...

"Look, I helped you solve that case with the magician, didn't I?  At least you could give me the benefit of the doubt or something."

She looked at her watch.  Four minutes.  She sighed and her entire demeanor changed.

"I guess I could get 'em there.  We gotta talk about the evidence that the forensics are processing anyway."

Thirty seconds later, I heard the announcement over the intercom.  3:30 until she knew that my fingerprints were on the knife.  3:30 to prove whodunit.  Unfortunately, it would take another minute-and-half for the suspects to get there...

---

Two minutes.  It was an estimate, but I hoped they would get the evidence processed later rather than sooner, in any case.

There they all stood.  Jack Schilling.  Ben Locust.  Cliff Packer.  Rick Mouri.  Hector Carlyle.  Detective Linger.

"Dude, what the heck is this all about?!"

Jack Schilling used more colorful words, but I'd rather not write exactly what he said here.

"The guy in charge of this place testified that no one entered the arena through the main entrance.  Additionally, there is an emergency exit in this arena, but if someone were to use this door, the alarm would sound.  Therefore, the murderer is obviously one of us."

No reactions.

"No duh, Sherlock."  (Again, Jack's language is too colorful for this account.)

"Additionally, the murderer had to be someone who knew Keith Haley well enough."

"Why is that?" asked Detective Linger.

"Remember that there was no blood found on the victim's vest.  The victim's vest was obviously removed before he was stabbed.  There would only be two ways that this was done - by incapacitating the victim first, or by the victim removing it himself.

"Also, remember how stuffy it was in here.  It's hard enough already for normal people to breathe, but..."

I pulled out Keith's inhaler from his pocket.

"...for someone with asthma, it would be even more difficult.

"It makes sense, then, that the killer accompanied the victim until the victim had trouble breathing.  The victim decided to take a rest, and the killer, being the great friend he was, decided to help the victim rest.  The victim removed his vest and backed into the wall.  The killer then took out a knife and... killed him.

"Of course, the trick can only be done if the killer knows the victim has asthma, and...-"

I was cut off by an ominous ringtone.  I froze.  Detective Linger pulled out the phone and answered it.  She listened, nodded a few times, and stared coldly at me.  She hung up.

"You're just trying to cover up for yourself, aren't you?!" she exclaimed.

"I'm not...  If you'll let me explain the rest of the case, you'll understand how my knife ended up in the victim..."

The three college guys smirked and my two friends looked straight at me.

"You."  I pointed to Jack Schilling in the white.  "You remember stealing my money, right?"

He looked at me and still smirked.

"Little did you notice, not only did you steal my money, but you also snatched my pocketknife!"

Suddenly, Jack Schilling's face looked very serious.

"I never killed Keith!"

"I never said you killed Keith," I replied.

"But I didn't!!" Jack shouted.

"No...  You're right...  You didn't kill Keith.  Someone else did.  Someone you gave the money to."

Jack gave a short chuckle.  "You don't know who I gave the money to.  That, and I'm not talking."

I pointed my accusing finger.

"You, Cliff Packer."

The tattoo and red shirt looked impervious to my accusation, and he looked like he would kill me were there not so many officers around.

"You're an idiot," he told me.

"It makes sense, though.  You had to hide the vest somewhere, or someone would see Keith's body lying on the ground.  You couldn't hide it behind Keith, because his body would trip someone.  You couldn't just hide it anywhere in the arena, because people would see it and wonder where the vest's owner went."
