I smiled.

"Jack Schilling, how many times were you shot by Cliff?" I asked.

"I don't remember!" he said.

"Why don't you check your scorecard.  It's recorded there."

He looked and saw that very thing that I saw... rather, he didn't see what should have been there.

"Ben Locust, how many times were you shot by Cliff?"

He pulled out his card and didn't see it either.

"Rick?"

Not there.

"Hector?"

Not there, either.  I pulled out my own card.  It wasn't there either.

"I'm sure I was shot by everyone here at least twice, except Hector.  Yet, when I look under your name, Cliff... it shows me..."

I turned my card around and showed him.

"It shows me that you didn't hit me at all.  In fact, it shows me that Keith hit me quite a lot, even though I could have sworn you hit me at least ten times...  Isn't that strange...?"

---

"I wasn't originally going to kill him..."

There was a few minutes of silence before Cliff confessed.

"That is, until I found that knife in my pocket.

"I was originally going to just bash his head in.  That bastard..."

"Why..." I began.

"Because that sonuvabitch blackmailed me!  Why the hell do you think I needed to steal money today!?"

His eyes were swelling, and I thought it ironic that a man with a tattoo was about to cry.

"My younger sister lives at home, and every weekend he'd... check up on her!

"I caught him spying on my sister when I went home once, and he... he told me that if I told anyone about what he was doing, he'd... he'd kill my sister!

"I didn't believe him...  I hired a P.I. and asked her to watch Keith and make sure he wasn't going anywhere near my sister...  That P.I... what a goddamn joke.  He got found the first day on the job!

"I told Keith I had nothing to do with it, but the next day... I got a call from my sister...  She told me...  She told me that her right hand was broken!...

"She loved the violin, and to have her hand broken...  Even after that, he told me that I would have to pay him now!  He told me... each week I didn't pay him... he'd break off another finger...!

"I had nothing else to do.  I'd already hired a detective and talked to the police...  No one would take me seriously!  I did the only thing I could do...!"

And there it was.  A few tears.  I felt like snickering... it was strange sight... yet...!</lj-cut>

<lj-cut>And there it was.  My pocket knife.  In Keith Haley's heart.  I froze and gazed at it.

"James... You didn't... kill him, did you?"

Hector was staring at the body as well.

"Idiot!  Of course not!"

"Well, your fingerprints will be found on the murder weapon, though, won't they?"

I reached in my pocket and pulled out a tissue.  It was almost automatic.  It was as if my body were moving on its own.  Inside, I was telling myself to... to wipe down the weapon... and I was telling myself not to tamper with evidence...  The tissue was draped over the weapon now.  A few swipes, and...

"What are you doing, James?"

Hector was there, witnessing the whole thing.  I wanted to tell him to go away... to turn the other cheek... and he would...  I know he would...

"Hector..."

He stared at my hand.

"James, if you didn't do it, then the evidence will show that.  It doesn't matter how many fingerprints of yours there are on that knife."

I looked at my hand.  I looked at Keith's face.  His blue eyes seemed to turn to me... watching me...  Telling me not to do it...  My hand slowly lifted the tissue up, and I put it back in my pocket.

---

I walked out without saying a word to anyone.  I had to find out what really happened before the forensics team was able to analyze the weapon.

"What?!"

I was sitting on a bench outside the arena and overheard Detective Linger on the phone.

"Whaddya mean the fingerprint analysis won't be here for another ten minutes?!  Look, I got kids runnin' around the crime scene, and you want me to hold them off until you can finish processing all the evidence?!..."

Ten minutes.  Ten minutes to go over what I knew.  I needed to think fast:

"The knife was stabbed through the heart.  That obviously meant that the vest was removed before Keith was stabbed, but how was it removed?  And why was it removed beforehand?  Could it be he went in there without his vest?  Impossible.  The guy would have seen him.  And there was no blood on any of the vests, so no one carried him there, nor did they stab him with his vest still on...  It's strange, because it would make sense to kill him before removing his vest.  So why would he have consented...?

"Furthermore, how did my knife end up in that person?  Could it be that someone pickpocketed me again?  No, I was careful with my stuff... I doubt it...  But it's definitely possible.  Then again, why would someone steal my knife?  Also, how did they know I would have something like that?

"The only people who know that I carry a knife around with me are Chris, Rick, and Hector.  Chris wasn't hear, so that implied either Rick or Hector... but they are my friends!  Why would they do something like that?  Would they do something like that?!

"Wait a second...!  Rick was the last one out!  In fact, I had to go searching for him then!  Could it be...!?

"That's not right.  Rick doesn't even know the guy... at least I don't think he does...

"Hold it!  During the game...!  I thought there was something strange there...!  Maybe... if that's what it says on the scorecard...  After all, I was shot by everyone at least twice, and I'm sure of it..."

I pulled out my scorecard and looked under every name...

"It's not there...  That explains it!  That's how he removed the vest before killing him!  That's why the body was there!  That's where the vest was hidden...!"

I smiled.  The means, the motive, and the decisive evidence.  No doubt the murderer was him...!</lj-cut>

<lj-cut>The police had arrived and the lights all were lit in that laser tag place.  It was odd to actually be able to see where I was going in there, though breathing was still another question.

The place was crawling with detectives and investigators and whatnot, so it was impossible for me to examine the scene right now.  Instead, I was in questioning along with the six other survivors.

I learned the names of the other four.  The dead guy was Keith Haley.  His white shirt and wide eyes reflected what little light there was when I first saw him.  His gold hair and blue eyes shone even brighter each time I was able to catch a glance of the body.

The one with the black beer shirt was Jack Schilling.  His jeans were torn, though I could tell the tears were fake - the tears were above the knee cap which made absolutely no sense.  The guy's hair was messier than my own, and he looked like one of those guys who didn't give a damn about anyone else.  I found him annoying.

There was the guy in blue.  His hair was all black.  In fact, it was so unnaturally black, it almost looked blue in good light.  He was wearing black eyeliner that was obviously uneven in thickness.  He looked like a person who was about to go running around holding a knife, only to dig it into his own arm.  The police called him Ben Locust.

Then there was the guy in red - Cliff Packer.  He, too, had dark hair, though I presumed it was naturally dark.  He looked more muscular than his companions, though not much more, and I noticed at tattoo on his left arm.  I didn't think highly of him either, especially when I saw mucus leave his mouth and hit the ground.  I looked under my own shoe and found similar mucus.  I felt a little sick after that...

"Kid!"

I wasn't used to being questioned, I was used to investigating the crime scene, not being questioned, though it looked like the entire case was going to revolve around interrogation.  There was no way the evidence would implicate anyone, nor would there be any eye-witnesses owing to how pitch-black it was, but I was still itching to go to the case... itching...!!

"James Hamish!!"

I jumped.  The cop was looking very irritated.

"Sorry, officer."

"Well?  Describe the chain of events to me, if you please!"

---

Fifteen minutes of questioning for each of us, and we were free from questioning, though not so from being at the scene.  I asked the officer who was questioning me who was in charge of the scene.

"That would be Detective Linger."

Detective Jean Linger had worked with me a month or so before on an apparent suicide.  She was very well built, probably even moreso than most cops on the job.  She was about 6 feet tall, and would easily be able to snap people's backs in half with her bare hands.  She was black, and her hair was short, probably because it was more convenient to have it short than have it flowing all over the place and getting in her way.  Unlike the other detectives, however, who liked to run around in trenchcoats and ties and hats and the typical attire, she wore a uniform herself.

She was reasonable, so at least revealing what happened wouldn't be too tough when I found out whodunit before she did.

I thanked the officer and left.

Since the body was still surrounded by officers and whatnot, I decided to go to the vest where I found some officers using luminol spray to look for blood on the vests.  An officer was questioning the guy working there, and asked him if anyone else could possibly have come in at the time.

"Nope.  I stand guard here so no one gets free games, and the emergency door's alarm would have gone off if someone used it."

The murderer was one of those three, and judging from their intelligence, it wasn't going to be a tough case.

I watched as the officer working with the vests unstacked a pair of vests and continued checking for luminol.  Hector was watching with wide eyes and taking mental notes.  If he had pencil and paper, the paper would have been filled front-and-back faster than you could give it to him.

"They find anything, Hector?"

"Shh!!"

He watched intently as the officer picked up the last vest and found no luminol.  Nothing.  Hector and I looked at each other.

I walked outside to the arcade and on my way out was handed my scorecard.  I wasn't interested, so I stuffed it in my pocket.  I sat on a bench waiting for some officers to come out, indicating that the body was probably clear...

---

A half-hour passed until I saw a few police officers walk out and presumed it would be ok to investigate the body now.  I walked to the body and noticed Rick was already there, staring intently at something.  I waved to Rick and called out his name.  He looked confused when he saw me and ran off...

I studied the body myself.  Stabbed through the heart.  Scrunched against the wall.  Unnatural position.  Probably so people wouldn't trip over him.  I felt in his pocket.  Inhaler still there.  The bright blue eyes were directed toward the sky and the mouth was agape as if it would start screaming.

I heard footsteps and turned around to see Hector staring at the body himself.  He took off his glasses and wiped them as if he was having trouble seeing.  He knelt down, too.

"What do you deduce, James?" he asked.

I looked at the body and made gestures as I spoke.  "Obviously stabbed through the heart.  He was smashed against the wall so he wouldn't be discovered.  I think I know what happened to him, but something's still bothering me..."

"Is it the same thing that's bothering me, James?"

I turned to look at Hector.  He was staring straight at me.  It was a strangely cold stare.  It was as if he was telling me there was something very wrong with the body.  Very wrong.  It was as if he was accusing me...

I looked back at the body and saw exactly what it was that bothered me.  I shuddered and felt weak.  I felt my pockets and overturned them, revealing a few bucks in cash and my penlight.  But it wasn't there.  It wasn't in my pocket.  It wasn't in my pocket because I was staring right at it.

There it was.  In the victim's chest.  My pocket-knife.</lj-cut>

"Sucker!"

My assailant fled like the coward he was. I would give chase, but I was already incapacitated. My gun shut off. I was left alone in the dark.

"Damn you, Rick!"

"Don't worry about it, James! It's just a game of laser tag!"

Hector Carlyle was standing behind me. His figure wasn't very imposing and neither were his glasses. His clothes draped over him and gave him the appearance of well-fed kid, but he was anything but. He was sweating slight beads that coated his acne and his head darted around, looking for enemies.

"Hah! Me take it easy? Look at you moving your head all over the place! And there's no one around!"

"What do you mean there's no one around?"

"Well, you can't hear anyone around but us two, can you?"

"I can't hear anything around here with that music blaring!"

It really was like I imagined a rave might be. The sweat, the poor lighting, the loud music, the sweat, the lack of drinks... The only thing different was we were high school kids running around shooting other high school kids with toy guns.

My gun and vest lit back up, and I was ready to kill. And my first target...

"What the...?! James, I thought you said there wasn't anyone around! James? James?!"

At least I got one kill this game...

---

Each game lasted fifteen minutes - plenty of time to lose all body fluids. Everyone came out drenched, and you were so wet all over, you could very well have wet your pants without knowing it.

"Thanks for abandoning me, James."

Hector walked out sweaty and breathing hard. In the light you could see his Mexican heritage and short dark hair and eyes. He took off his glasses and wiped them on his shirt only to find that his shirt probably made it worse for his glasses.

"I'm going to wipe these off in the bathroom."

"Hey, Hector! Where you goin'?!"

Hector tried to give his most intimidating face and walked off.

"Traitor."

I smirked and punched him in the arm.

"Damn. And you would think someone like you would actually pack a punch."

Rick Mouri was a football player, so of course he'd break your arm as soon as he'd touch it. He looked like he should have been in college, partially owing to his mustache and beard which were steady works-in-progress. If Hector looked like the brains of the three of us, Rick was the brawns, and I was the misfit.

"You up for a few more games?" Rick asked, effectively paralyzing my other arm with his fist.

"A couple more. I gotta get back home, soon," I responded.

"Right, you gotta get to your girlfriend, Chris."

Chris Perry was hospitalized for her cigarette burn which she got during one of my investigations. From what I heard latest, she wasn't yet released, so I figured I'd give her my regards. Interestingly, Chris figured out that case about the same time I did, the only difference being she confronted the criminal, who burned her with a lit cigarette. They said the scar would heal...

I looked at the line of people already in line for the next game and looked to the restrooms.

"Hector better get back soon or the next game will start..." I thought to myself.

I looked back at the line when some guy bumped into me from behind, nearly knocking me over.

"Watch it!!"

The words came out of Rick's mouth as he shook his fist at the guy. He must have been about twenty, and he looked like he was going to play his first game of the day. He wore a black shirt advertising some kind of beer. He met up with some other guys in line and they bought keys for the next game. See, each of the lasers were activated by a kind of activation key which somehow held magnetic information or whatnot about something. Point was - each person playing needed a key so they could play and get their stats afterward.

The next game was about to start, and those other guys made their way to the door which led to that stuffy place I was just in.

Hector came out of the restroom just as they were starting the next game. The three of us rushed to get the activation keys in time, but it was already too late, and the next game had already started. Not only that, but...

"Damn, I thought I brought more money than this..."

I was ten bucks short now. Of course, I knew who it must have been, but I wasn't about to waste my breath pursuing ten bucks I wouldn't get back.

"Looks like I only got enough for one more game, guys."

Rick looked disappointed, but Hector didn't seem to mind. We got our keys...

---

We were inside the "de-briefing room", which looked a lot like the laser tag "arena", except it wasn't quite as sweaty, and it definitely wasn't as big. The rules were being explained, and only Hector listened, and listened avidly at that. I looked around and noticed the four guys who had taken my money earlier. The one who was wearing a white shirt pulled out an inhaler and puffed. Apparently, one of them had asthma...

I looked at my opponents. It looked as if it was just going to be the seven of us - me, Hector, Rick, Black Beer Shirt, Puffer, and two other guys. I made quick mental notes of shirt colors... red, blue...

"James!"

It was Hector.

"Aren't you listening? They said that we're not supposed to run in there...!"

I rolled my eyes. Seriously, Hector? Seriously?

---

After another five minutes of "explaining rules" and we were in that dark and sweaty cage once again... I teamed up with Hector. Rick, of course, went on his own way. Together, Hector and I made the absolutely worst alliance. We must have ben shot by everyone there at least twice.

We were split up, but I knew from the ominous clanking noise behind me that I was the one being chased. I rounded the corner and held my gun ready. Red rounded the corner and I pulled my trigger.

Nothing. I pulled again. Red started walking away.

"What the...?"

"The game ended already, James!"

Hector was running up to me and showing his watch. I looked at my gun. "GAME OVER."

We rushed back to the entrance, and I took off my vest. I was exhausted and glad it was my last game.

"Where's Rick?" Hector asked.

I looked back at the "arena".

"I'll get him..."

---

After calling out for a bit, I found Rick. Evidently, he thought we were still playing, so I explained that he needed to come back. He ran ahead of me, and as I was on my way back...

I hit the floor. There was something on the ground... I turned around and pulled out my penlight...

And there was, knelt on the floor, back against the wall, scrunched up in a corner, and with a knife through his heart. There was Puffer, white shirt stained red. I checked his vitals. Nothing.

<lj-cut>It was the cold feeling of being followed that I hadn't felt since that kidnapping case on the train where I was greeted with a loaded weapon.  This time, I had one myself, but how can you defend yourself from someone you can't see?

Pitch black except the few lights so I could navigate my way.  I could feel him...  I could feel him... chasing me...

I rushed around a corner and up a ramp, running as silently as I could.  No time to look down and around.  My thoughts ran faster than my legs, but my heart was racing even faster.  If only my lungs were working as fast.  It was getting hard to breathe.  Too hard...

I rushed down another ramp, rounded another corner, and looked behind me, catching my breath.

"Damn.  Where is he...?!"

Eyes strained, but saw nothing.  I rested a few more seconds and turned around to find a gun pressed against my chest.  I looked up.  A smirk with slightly crooked teeth.  A short laugh.  I felt like the gun pressed even deeper.  My insides churned...

I watched as the finger rested on the trigger, ready to fire.  My gun was at my side, and it would have been too slow... if only...!

"Goodbye, Detective James Hamish."

The trigger.  Darkness.  I staggered back.</lj-cut>

<lj-cut>"So how long did Mr. Galactica practice magic?"

I was talking with Ms. Clay by the staircase.

"Years.  Maybe fifteen years.  I've worked with him for fourteen years as his faithful assistant."

"How long has Mr. Galactica done the guillotine act?"

"Well, about a few weeks now.  I don't know how it works, but I do know that the blade is real, as I cut myself on it once.  I also know that it was specially designed by Bill Chinkerhoff, which is obvious because of the rope that drops the blade down and the unique design, but besides that, I don't know."

There was no mistaking it now...  The murderer, the method, the decisive evidence...  It was all in my hands.  The only problem was getting the others to listen...

---

"Dad?"

"Yeah?"

I was talking to my uncle inside Mr. Galactica's room.

"Could you call Mr. Merryl, Ms. Clay, Mr. Chinkerhoff, and Detective Linger to this room?" I asked.

"Why?"

"Well, I have a few questions to ask them and a few things I want clarified..."

"I guess I could."

My uncle walked off to get the others, apparently clueless.

---

Me, my uncle, Mr. Merryl, Ms. Clay, Mr. Chinkerhoff, and Detective Linger were standing around the doorway of Mr. Galactica's room.  I stood off to one side and they to another so I was able to keep an eye on all of them at once.

"It's strange that Mr. Galactica would commit suicide, isn't it?  Especially with such a great career and life," I commented.

"Well, not everyone who's popular necessarily has a happy life.  I've seen other celebrities and such commit suicide as well..." responded Detective Linger.

"It's not just that that was bothering me, though...  Don't you remember that the hands were found cut off as well as the head?  If I were committing suicide, I wouldn't care where my hands were," I explained.

"That is true... but if it's not a suicide, what are you suggesting?" asked Detective Linger.

"There can be only two possibilities, then.  Either this was an accident, or this was a murder..."

I watched the reactions of the three suspects.  Each looked at one another, suspecting anyone but themselves.

"It could have been Jean Clay," said Mr. Merryl.  "She's been working with Leon Galactica for a long time, but she's always been seen in his eyes as an underling.  They were always having arguments and he always said she couldn't make it on her own or start her own show."

"In that case," said Mr. Chinkerhoff, "you have enough motive yourself, Merryl.  You haven't had a pay raise in five years, and every time you ask for a bonus or raise, he never gives it to you.  Hell, he throws you out the door himself."  Considering Mr. Merryl's size, I might take that literally.

"Will, you're not exactly without a motive yourself," said Ms. Clay.  "You get all of what, one week's vacation.  And by vacation, that also means sick days.  You got tricked into that contract where if you took more time for vacation, you would be without a month's pay.  You couldn't take him to court if you tried."

"Enough."

I needed to get back on track.

"You all have some kind of motive, but there is only one way this could have happened.

"Mr. Chinkerhoff, your story is quite simple.  You were downstairs preparing the meal the entire time, so you couldn't have murdered Mr. Galactica then.  Also, if you did, Ms. Clay would have noticed when she went up and delivered the food."  I motioned toward the food on the end table.

"Mr. Chinkerhoff, you also didn't go anywhere during dinner, so you couldn't have possibly killed Mr. Galactica.

"Ms. Clay.  When you first went upstairs to deliver Mr. Galactica his food, I assume he was still alive, or you would have gotten our attention.  Also, the food was inside, so I think you did deliver him the food.

"But isn't it strange that the water was the only thing Mr. Galactica had?  Maybe he didn't eat the rest of his food because he couldn't.  Maybe he couldn't because the poison had already worked its effects, at which point you could have staged the whole thing as an accident."

"That's it!" my uncle remarked.  "No wonder you were gone for fifteen minutes!  You were busy waiting for the poison to work, so you could kill Mr. Galactica!!"

"That's not true!"  Ms. Clay looked angrily at my uncle and me.  "That's not-"

"Of course," I interrupted, "the room was locked, and you couldn't have gone out by using the ladder, because you were wearing heels, and the only footprints outside were footprints of someone wearing small shoes.

"Speaking of which, Mr. Merryl, you could have set this up as a locked room case yourself.  You could have had the ladder ready, entered through the door to Mr. Galactica's room, strangled him with the rope on the ground, killed him with the guillotine, and left using the ladder, all while locking the door behind you.  The second story window doesn't lock, does it?"

"So the murderer must be Mr. Merryl!" my uncle shouted.  "You saw a dead body because you created it yourself, didn't you!?"

"You're accusing your old friend of murderering another friend?!" Mr. Merryl screeched.

"Look, Mr. Merryl couldn't have killed Mr. Galactica either.  There were only two sets of footprints found.  One was going to put the ladder there, and one was coming back from the ladder.  If Mr. Merryl killed Mr. Galactica, locked the room, and left through the window, there would be three footprints - one from planting the ladder, one from coming back into the house, and one from coming back after committing the murder."

"So... it was an accident?" my uncle asked.

"Not quite.  It couldn't really be that," I continued, "because Mr. Galactica had only been practicing the trick for a few weeks.  He would never try something so dangerous if the trick behind it wasn't so easy.  He wouldn't try it with a sharp blade, at least, and Mr. Galactica always tried the trick with a sharp blade, right Ms. Clay?"

She nodded.

"So what happened?!" my uncle asked impatiently.

"It was both - an accident and a murder."

Everyone looked confused.

"Look, the real guillotine trick must have been easy to perform, but something went wrong which caused Mr. Galactica to die.  But that something going wrong was planned."

I called everyone over to where the guillotine was and pointed to the two square-like indentations in the carpet.

"These indentations mean that the guillotine wasn't in the same place as it was before.  Why was the guillotine moved?  To replace it with this guillotine...!!"

And there was the reaction I suspected from that person...  That person knew I had seen right through them.

"There are actually two guillotines - one guillotine was the real one Mr. Galactica used for his magic trick.  The other is this fake one that actually killed Mr. Galactica!"

"So the murderer must be..." Detective Linger looked at him.  "You!  William Chinkerhoff!"

He looked shocked at first, but tried to explain it away.

"You're kidding!  You're saying I made two look-alike guillotines so I could kill Mr. Galactica?" asked Mr. Chinkerhoff.

"That's exactly what I'm saying," I replied.

"Tell me," I continued, "how does the guillotine work?"

"When the cord is pulled, the bottom part of the guillotine falls so Mr. Galactica falls through before the blade can slice him, but..." said Mr. Chinkerhoff.

"But it just happened not to work?" I asked.

"If you're going to accuse me, you're going to have to tell me why it couldn't possibly have been any of these other people!"  He grabbed me by my collar.  "Do you have any proof?!  Do you?!"

I pointed and smiled.

"The guillotine?!"

"That's it," I told him.  "Ms. Clay told me that you made the guillotine special for Mr. Galactica.  It was special because of how the guillotine was activated.  By that cord within reach of Mr. Galactica.  The fact that the guillotine is so unique and that Mr. Galactica was fooled to believe it was the same guillotine could only mean that you crafted the guillotine yourself.

"You were planning on killing Mr. Galactica for a while because he wouldn't give you any time away from work.  You just had to wait until your great project was complete.  There is but one problem in your method, and that is just how unique your guillotine is, Mr. Chinkerhoff."
